policy_title: Introduction
summary: Sets out the Government's planning policies for England and how they should be applied, providing a framework for locally-prepared plans to achieve sustainable housing and other development. Emphasises preparing and maintaining up-to-date plans as a priority.

policy_title: Application of Planning Law and the Framework
summary: States that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise. The National Planning Policy Framework must be taken into account in preparing the development plan and is a material consideration in planning decisions. Policies and decisions must also reflect international obligations and statutory requirements.
cross_references: footnote 3 (Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 and section 70(2) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990)

policy_title: Reading and Applying the Framework
summary: Stipulates that the Framework should be read as a whole, including its footnotes and annexes. General references to planning policies in the Framework should be applied appropriately to the type of plan being produced, considering policy on plan-making in chapter 3.

policy_title: Relationship with Other Planning Policies (Traveller Sites and Waste)
summary: Requires the Framework to be read in conjunction with the Government's planning policy for traveller sites and its planning policy for waste. Regard should be had to NPPF policies, where relevant, when preparing plans or making decisions for these types of development.

policy_title: Scope Regarding Nationally Significant Infrastructure Projects
summary: Clarifies that the Framework does not contain specific policies for nationally significant infrastructure projects (NSIPs). NSIPs are determined in accordance with the Planning Act 2008 and relevant national policy statements, though the NPPF may be a material consideration.

policy_title: Other Material Government Policy Statements
summary: Notes that other statements of government policy, such as relevant Written Ministerial Statements and endorsed recommendations of the National Infrastructure Commission, may be material when preparing plans or deciding applications.

policy_title: Purpose of the Planning System and Sustainable Development
summary: States the planning system's purpose is to contribute to the achievement of sustainable development, including providing homes, commercial development and infrastructure sustainably. Defines sustainable development's objective as meeting present needs without compromising future generations' ability to meet their own, and notes the UK's commitment to the 17 Global Goals for Sustainable Development up to 2030.
cross_references: footnote 4 (Resolution 42/187 of the United Nations General Assembly)
footnote 5 (Transforming our World: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development)
targets: period to 2030 (Global Goals)

policy_title: Overarching Objectives of Sustainable Development
summary: Defines that achieving sustainable development means the planning system has three interdependent overarching objectives to be pursued in mutually supportive ways: an economic objective (building a strong economy with sufficient land for growth and infrastructure); a social objective (supporting strong communities with sufficient housing and well-designed places); and an environmental objective (protecting and enhancing the environment, using resources prudently, and mitigating/adapting to climate change).

policy_title: Delivering Sustainable Development Objectives
summary: Specifies that the three overarching objectives for sustainable development should be delivered through plan preparation, implementation, and policy application. Planning policies and decisions should actively guide development towards sustainable solutions, taking local circumstances into account to reflect each area's character, needs and opportunities. These objectives are not criteria against which every decision is judged.

policy_title: Heart of the Framework: Presumption in Favour
summary: Establishes that a presumption in favour of sustainable development (detailed in paragraph 11) is at the heart of the Framework, ensuring sustainable development is pursued positively.

policy_title: Applying the Presumption in Favour of Sustainable Development
summary: Mandates that plans and decisions should apply a presumption in favour of sustainable development, outlining specific implications for plan-making and decision-taking.

policy_title: Plan-Making: Promoting Sustainable Development Patterns
summary: For plan-making, requires all plans to promote a sustainable pattern of development that seeks to: meet development needs of their area; align growth and infrastructure; improve the environment; mitigate climate change (including by making effective use of land in urban areas) and adapt to its effects.

policy_title: Plan-Making: Strategic Policies for Assessed Needs
summary: For plan-making, mandates strategic policies should, as a minimum, provide for objectively assessed needs for housing and other uses, and any needs from neighbouring areas that cannot be met, unless specific exceptions apply.
cross_references: footnote 6 (As established through statements of common ground (see paragraph 28))

policy_title: Plan-Making Exception: Protection of Important Areas/Assets
summary: Provides an exception to meeting assessed needs in plan-making if the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a strong reason for restricting the overall scale, type or distribution of development in the plan area.

policy_title: Plan-Making Exception: Adverse Impacts Outweigh Benefits
summary: Provides an exception to meeting assessed needs in plan-making if any adverse impacts of doing so would significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against the policies in this Framework taken as a whole.

policy_title: Decision-Taking: Approving Proposals in Accord with Up-to-Date Plan
summary: For decision-taking, this means approving development proposals that accord with an up-to-date development plan without delay.

policy_title: Decision-Taking: Granting Permission Where Plan Policies Are Absent or Out-of-Date
summary: For decision-taking, where there are no relevant development plan policies, or the most important policies are out-of-date, this means granting permission unless specific exceptions apply.
cross_references: footnote 8 (This includes, for applications involving the provision of housing, situations where: the local planning authority cannot demonstrate a five year supply of deliverable housing sites... or where the Housing Delivery Test indicates... delivery was substantially below (less than 75% of) the housing requirement... See also paragraph 232.)
targets: five year supply of deliverable housing sites (footnote 8)
Housing Delivery Test less than 75% (footnote 8)

policy_title: Decision-Taking Exception: Protection of Important Areas/Assets (No/Outdated Plan)
summary: Provides an exception to granting permission (where plans are absent/outdated) if the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a strong reason for refusing the development proposed.
cross_references: footnote 7 (The policies referred to are those in this Framework ... relating to: habitats sites ... Sites of Special Scientific Interest; land designated as Green Belt, Local Green Space, a National Landscape, a National Park ... Heritage Coast; irreplaceable habitats; designated heritage assets ...; and areas at risk of flooding or coastal change.)
geographic_mentions: areas at risk of coastal change

policy_title: Decision-Taking Exception: Adverse Impacts Outweigh Benefits (No/Outdated Plan)
summary: Provides an exception to granting permission (where plans are absent/outdated) if any adverse impacts of doing so would significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against policies in this Framework as a whole, with particular regard to key policies for sustainable locations, land use, design, and affordable homes.
cross_references: footnote 9 (The policies referred to are those in paragraphs 66 and 84 of chapter 5; 91 of chapter 7; 110 and 115 of chapter 9; 129 of chapter 11; and 135 and 139 of chapter 12.)

policy_title: Statutory Status of the Development Plan
summary: Clarifies that the presumption in favour of sustainable development does not change the statutory status of the development plan as the starting point for decision-making. Permission should not usually be granted for applications conflicting with an up-to-date development plan (including neighbourhood plans), unless material considerations indicate otherwise.

policy_title: Implications for Neighbourhood Planning
summary: States that the application of the presumption has implications for community engagement in neighbourhood planning. Neighbourhood plans should support the delivery of strategic policies in local plans or spatial development strategies and shape/direct development outside these strategic policies.

policy_title: Neighbourhood Plan Protection in Housing Applications (Presumption 11d)
summary: In situations where the presumption (paragraph 11d) applies to housing applications, the adverse impact of allowing development conflicting with a neighbourhood plan is likely to significantly and demonstrably outweigh benefits, provided the neighbourhood plan became part of the development plan five years or less before the decision, and it contains policies/allocations for its identified housing requirement.
targets: five years or less (neighbourhood plan age)

policy_title: Genuinely Plan-Led System
summary: Emphasises that the planning system should be genuinely plan-led. Succinct and up-to-date plans should provide a positive vision, a framework for meeting housing and other needs, and a platform for local people to shape their surroundings.

policy_title: Characteristics of Plans
summary: Outlines key characteristics plans should exhibit: prepared for sustainable development; positively prepared (aspirational but deliverable); shaped by early and effective engagement; contain clear and unambiguous policies; accessible via digital tools; and serve a clear purpose, avoiding unnecessary duplication.
cross_references: footnote 10 (legal requirement for LPA plan-making functions - section 39(2) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004)

policy_title: Strategic Policies in Development Plans
summary: Requires the development plan to include strategic policies addressing each local planning authority's priorities for development and land use. These can be in joint or individual local plans or in a spatial development strategy from an elected Mayor or combined authority with plan-making powers.
cross_references: footnote 11 (Section 19(1B-1E) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004)

policy_title: Non-Strategic Policies
summary: States that policies addressing non-strategic matters should be included in local plans (with strategic policies) and/or in local or neighbourhood plans containing only non-strategic policies.

policy_title: Composition of the Development Plan
summary: Defines the development plan for an area as the combination of strategic and non-strategic policies in force at a particular time.

policy_title: Content of Strategic Policies
summary: Strategic policies should set out an overall strategy for the pattern, scale and design quality of places and make sufficient provision for homes (including affordable), employment, retail, leisure, infrastructure (transport, communications, waste, water, energy, minerals), community facilities, and conservation/enhancement of the environment (including climate change measures).
cross_references: footnote 12 (In line with the presumption in favour of sustainable development)

policy_title: Identification and Scope of Strategic Policies
summary: Plans should make explicit which policies are strategic. These should be limited to addressing strategic priorities (and cross-boundary issues) and provide a clear starting point for non-strategic policies. Strategic policies should not cover detailed matters better dealt with in neighbourhood plans or other non-strategic policies.
cross_references: footnote 13 (Where a single local plan is prepared the non-strategic policies should be clearly distinguished from the strategic policies)

policy_title: Time Horizon for Strategic Policies
summary: Strategic policies should look ahead over a minimum 15-year period from adoption to anticipate long-term needs and opportunities. For large-scale developments like new settlements or significant extensions, policies should be set within a vision looking further ahead (at least 30 years) to account for delivery timescales.
cross_references: footnote 14 (Except in relation to town centre development, as set out in chapter 7)
footnote 15 (Transitional arrangements are set out in Annex 1)
targets: minimum 15 year period from adoption
at least 30 years vision for large-scale developments

policy_title: Indicating Development Locations and Land Supply in Strategic Policies
summary: Strategic policies should indicate broad locations for development on a key diagram and identify land-use designations/allocations on a policies map. They must provide a clear strategy for bringing sufficient land forward at a sufficient rate to meet objectively assessed needs, including allocating sites for strategic priorities (unless met by other mechanisms like brownfield registers or non-strategic policies).
cross_references: footnote 16 (For spatial development strategies, allocations, land use designations and a policies map are needed only where the power to make allocations has been conferred.)

policy_title: Maintaining Effective Cooperation: Role of Strategic Planning
summary: Highlights the vital and increasing role of effective strategic planning across local planning authority boundaries for sustainable growth, addressing key spatial issues like housing needs, strategic infrastructure, and economic/climate resilience. Reinforces the duty to cooperate for local planning authorities and county councils on cross-boundary strategic matters.

policy_title: Collaboration in Identifying Strategic Matters
summary: Strategic policy-making authorities should collaborate to identify relevant strategic matters for their plans. They should also engage with local communities and relevant bodies (Local Nature Partnerships, Marine Management Organisation, county councils, infrastructure providers, elected Mayors, combined authorities without plan-making powers).

policy_title: Effective and On-going Joint Working
summary: States that effective and ongoing joint working between strategic policy-making authorities and relevant bodies is integral to producing a positively prepared and justified strategy. Joint working should help determine where additional infrastructure is needed and if development needs unmet within a plan area could be met elsewhere.

policy_title: Aligning Plan Policies and Ensuring Consistent Approaches
summary: Once collaborative matters are identified, strategic policy-making authorities must ensure their plan policies align as fully as possible with other bodies where a strategic relationship exists, and consider relevant infrastructure provider investment plans, unless there's clear justification otherwise. This includes ensuring consistent approaches to major infrastructure delivery, providing for unmet needs from neighbouring areas (per 11b), and managing cross-boundary allocations/designations.

policy_title: Statements of Common Ground
summary: To demonstrate effective ongoing joint working, strategic policy-making authorities should prepare and maintain one or more statements of common ground, documenting cross-boundary matters and cooperative progress. These should follow national guidance, be publicly available throughout plan-making for transparency, and inform decisions when plans/evidence are incomplete.

policy_title: Role of Non-Strategic Policies
summary: Non-strategic policies should be used by local planning authorities and communities to set out more detailed policies for specific areas, neighbourhoods, or development types. This can include allocating sites, local infrastructure/facility provision, design principles, conserving/enhancing the environment, and other development management policies.

policy_title: Neighbourhood Planning and Development Levels
summary: Neighbourhood planning empowers communities to develop a shared vision, shaping and delivering sustainable development by influencing local planning decisions. Neighbourhood plans should not promote less development than set out in area strategic policies or undermine those policies.
cross_references: footnote 17 (Neighbourhood plans must be in general conformity with the strategic policies contained in any development plan that covers their area.)

policy_title: Precedence of Neighbourhood Plan Policies
summary: Once a neighbourhood plan is in force, its policies take precedence over existing non-strategic policies in a local plan covering the same area where they conflict, unless superseded by subsequently adopted strategic or non-strategic policies.

policy_title: Evidence Base for Policies
summary: The preparation and review of all policies should be underpinned by relevant and up-to-date evidence. This evidence must be adequate, proportionate, focused on supporting and justifying the policies, and consider relevant market signals.

policy_title: Sustainability Appraisal
summary: Local plans and spatial development strategies must be informed by a sustainability appraisal meeting legal requirements. This should demonstrate how the plan addresses economic, social, and environmental objectives (including net gains opportunities). Significant adverse impacts should be avoided, alternatives pursued, and if unavoidable, mitigation or compensatory measures proposed.
cross_references: footnote 18 (The reference to relevant legal requirements refers to Strategic Environmental Assessment. Neighbourhood plans may require Strategic Environmental Assessment, but only where there are potentially significant environmental effects.)

policy_title: Reviewing and Updating Policies
summary: Policies in local plans and spatial development strategies should be reviewed at least every five years to assess if they need updating, and updated as necessary, no later than five years from adoption. Relevant strategic policies need updating at least every five years if their local housing need figure has changed significantly, or earlier if local housing need is expected to change significantly soon.
cross_references: footnote 19 (Reviews at least every five years are a legal requirement for all local plans (Regulation 10A of the Town and Country Planning (Local Planning) (England) Regulations 2012))
targets: at least once every five years (review)
no later than five years from adoption (update completion)
at least once every five years (strategic policies update if LHN changes)

policy_title: Development Contributions
summary: Plans should set out expected contributions from development, including levels/types of affordable housing and other infrastructure (education, health, transport, flood/water management, green/digital infrastructure). Such policies should not undermine plan deliverability.

policy_title: Examining Plans: Tests of Soundness
summary: Local plans and spatial development strategies are examined for legal/procedural compliance and soundness. A plan is 'sound' if it is: Positively prepared (meeting needs, accommodating unmet need where practical, consistent with sustainable development); Justified (appropriate strategy based on alternatives and evidence); Effective (deliverable, based on effective joint working on cross-boundary matters); and Consistent with national policy.
cross_references: footnote 20 (Where this relates to housing, such needs should be assessed using a clear and justified method, as set out in paragraph 62 of this Framework)

policy_title: Applying Soundness Tests to Non-Strategic Policies
summary: The tests of soundness (from para 36) will be applied proportionately to non-strategic policies in a local plan, considering their consistency with relevant strategic policies for the area.
cross_references: footnote 21 (Where these are contained in a local plan.)

policy_title: Neighbourhood Plan Basic Conditions
summary: Neighbourhood plans must meet 'basic conditions' and other legal requirements before coming into force. These are tested through an independent examination before proceeding to referendum.
cross_references: footnote 22 (As set out in paragraph 8 of Schedule 4B to the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended))

policy_title: Approach to Decision-Making on Proposed Development
summary: Local planning authorities should approach decisions on proposed development positively and creatively, using tools like brownfield registers and permission in principle. They should work proactively with applicants to secure developments improving economic, social, and environmental conditions, approving sustainable development applications where possible.

policy_title: Benefits of Early Engagement and Pre-application Discussion
summary: Highlights that early engagement significantly improves the efficiency and effectiveness of the planning application system. Good quality pre-application discussion enables better coordination and improved community outcomes.

policy_title: Local Authority Role in Encouraging Pre-application Engagement
summary: Local planning authorities should encourage take-up of their pre-application services and, where beneficial, encourage applicants (not legally required to) to engage with the local community and relevant consultees before submitting applications.

policy_title: Role of Statutory Consultees in Pre-application Stage
summary: Emphasises that resolving issues like infrastructure improvements and affordable housing at pre-application stage yields greater benefits. Statutory planning consultees must adopt an early, proactive approach and provide timely advice throughout the development process to assist LPAs in timely decisions and avoid applicant delays/costs.

policy_title: Participation of Other Consenting Bodies in Pre-application Discussions
summary: Encourages participation of other consenting bodies in pre-application discussions for early consideration of fundamental issues regarding a development's acceptability, even if other consents are needed later. Parallel processing of other consents should be encouraged to speed up the process.

policy_title: Importance of Right Information for Decision-Making
summary: Stresses that the right information is crucial for good decision-making, especially for formal assessments (EIA, HRA, flood risk). Applicants should discuss information needs with the LPA and expert bodies early to avoid delay.

policy_title: Local Authority Information Requirements for Applications
summary: Local planning authorities should publish a list of their information requirements for planning applications. These should be kept to the minimum needed for decisions and reviewed at least every two years. Only relevant, necessary, and material supporting information should be requested.
targets: reviewed at least every two years

policy_title: Consultation on Major Hazard Sites
summary: Local planning authorities should consult appropriate bodies when considering applications for siting of, or changes to, major hazard sites, installations or pipelines, or for development around them.

policy_title: Voluntary Planning Performance Agreements
summary: Applicants and LPAs should consider voluntary planning performance agreements (PPAs) where they might achieve a faster, more effective application process, particularly for large or complex applications.

policy_title: Determining Applications: Timescales and Development Plan
summary: Planning law requires applications to be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise. Decisions should be made as quickly as possible, within statutory timescales unless a longer period is agreed in writing.

policy_title: Weight Given to Emerging Plans
summary: LPAs may give weight to relevant policies in emerging plans based on: stage of preparation (more advanced = more weight); extent of unresolved objections (less significant = more weight); and degree of consistency with this Framework (closer = more weight).
cross_references: footnote 23 (During the transitional period for emerging plans, consistency should be tested against the version of the Framework as applicable, as set out in Annex 1.)

policy_title: Refusal on Grounds of Prematurity
summary: In the context of the Framework and sustainable development presumption, arguments of prematurity are unlikely to justify refusal unless the development is so substantial (or its cumulative effect so significant) that granting permission would undermine plan-making by predetermining key decisions central to an emerging plan, AND the emerging plan is at an advanced stage but not yet formally part of the development plan.

policy_title: Justification for Refusal on Prematurity Grounds
summary: Refusal on prematurity grounds is seldom justified if a draft plan is yet to be submitted for examination (or for a neighbourhood plan, before the LPA publicity period ends). If refused on prematurity, the LPA must clearly indicate how granting permission would prejudice the plan-making outcome.

policy_title: Use of Local Development Orders (LDOs)
summary: Encourages LPAs to use Local Development Orders to set the planning framework for particular areas or development categories where impacts are acceptable, especially to promote economic, social, or environmental gains.

policy_title: Neighbourhood Development Orders and Community Right to Build Orders
summary: Communities can use Neighbourhood Development Orders and Community Right to Build Orders to grant planning permission, requiring local community support via referendum. LPAs should take a proactive, positive approach, working collaboratively with community organisations to resolve issues before draft orders are submitted for examination.

policy_title: Use of Article 4 Directions to Remove Permitted Development Rights
summary: Restricts the use of Article 4 directions. For non-residential to residential change of use, they are limited to avoiding wholly unacceptable adverse impacts (e.g. loss of primary shopping area core). In other cases, to protect local amenity or well-being (e.g. demolition of local facilities). In all cases, they must be based on robust evidence and apply to the smallest geographical area possible.

policy_title: Restricting National Permitted Development Rights via Planning Conditions
summary: Planning conditions should not be used to restrict national permitted development rights unless there is clear justification to do so.

policy_title: Use of Conditions and Planning Obligations
summary: LPAs should consider if otherwise unacceptable development could be made acceptable via conditions or planning obligations. Planning obligations should only be used if unacceptable impacts cannot be addressed by a condition.

policy_title: Criteria for Planning Conditions
summary: Planning conditions should be kept to a minimum and only imposed if necessary, relevant to planning and the development, enforceable, precise, and reasonable. Agreeing conditions early is beneficial.
cross_references: footnote 24 (Sections 100ZA(4-6) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 will require the applicant's written agreement to the terms of a pre-commencement condition, unless prescribed circumstances apply.)

policy_title: Tests for Planning Obligations
summary: Planning obligations must only be sought if they meet all tests: necessary to make the development acceptable in planning terms; directly related to the development; and fairly and reasonably related in scale and kind to the development.
cross_references: footnote 25 (Set out in Regulation 122(2) of the Community Infrastructure Levy Regulations 2010.)

policy_title: Viability and Development Contributions
summary: Applications complying with up-to-date policies on contributions should be assumed viable. Applicants must demonstrate if particular circumstances justify a viability assessment at application stage. The weight given to such assessment is for the decision-maker, considering plan up-to-dateness and site circumstance changes. All viability assessments should follow national guidance, use standardised inputs, and be publicly available.

policy_title: Enforcement Action
summary: Effective enforcement is important for public confidence. Enforcement action is discretionary; LPAs should act proportionately. They should consider publishing a local enforcement plan detailing monitoring, investigation of alleged breaches, and action protocols.

policy_title: Objective of Delivering a Sufficient Supply of Homes
summary: To support the Government's objective of significantly boosting home supply, it's important that sufficient land of various types comes forward where needed, specific housing requirements are addressed, and permitted land is developed without unnecessary delay. The overall aim is to meet an area's identified housing need with an appropriate housing mix.

policy_title: Determining Minimum Housing Need
summary: Strategic policies should determine the minimum number of homes needed using a local housing need assessment conducted via the standard method in national planning practice guidance. Needs from neighbouring areas that cannot be met locally should also be accounted for in establishing the planned housing amount.

policy_title: Assessing and Reflecting Housing Needs for Different Groups
summary: Within the context of establishing need, the size, type, and tenure of housing for different community groups should be assessed and reflected in planning policies. Groups include those needing affordable housing (including Social Rent), families, looked after children, older people (retirement/care homes), students, people with disabilities, service families, travellers, renters, and those wishing to commission/build their own homes.
cross_references: footnote 26 (Evidence of need for looked after children... Children's Social Care Sufficiency Strategy.)
footnote 27 (Planning Policy for Traveller Sites... Annex 1 of that document.)
footnote 28 (Self Build and Custom Housebuilding Act 2015...)

policy_title: Meeting Identified Need for Affordable Housing On-Site
summary: Where an affordable housing need is identified, planning policies should specify the type required (including minimum Social Rent proportion) and expect it to be met on-site, unless off-site provision or a financial contribution in lieu is robustly justified and contributes to creating mixed, balanced communities.
cross_references: footnote 29 (Applying the definition in Annex 2 to this Framework.)

policy_title: Affordable Housing Thresholds and Brownfield Land
summary: Affordable housing should not be sought for non-major residential developments, except in designated rural areas (where policies may set a lower threshold of 5 units or fewer).
targets: lower threshold of 5 units or fewer (in designated rural areas)

policy_title: Affordable Housing Mix on Major Developments
summary: For major development involving housing, planning policies and decisions should expect the mix of affordable housing required to meet identified local needs across Social Rent, other affordable housing for rent, and affordable home ownership tenures. The requirement for a minimum 25% First Homes no longer applies, but First Homes can continue where LPAs judge they meet local need.
cross_references: footnote 30 (Equivalent to the existing gross floorspace...)
footnote 31 (The requirement to deliver a minimum of 25% of affordable housing as First Homes... no longer applies.)

policy_title: Affordable Housing 'Golden Rules' for Green Belt Development
summary: As part of the 'Golden Rules' for Green Belt development (paras 156-157), a specific affordable housing requirement should be set for major housing development on land proposed for Green Belt release or permitted within it. This requirement should be set at a higher level than otherwise applicable and require at least 50% affordable housing, unless unviable.
targets: at least 50% affordable housing

policy_title: Setting Affordable Housing Rates for Green Belt Land
summary: The affordable housing requirement for land within or released from the Green Belt can be a single rate or differential rates, subject to the criteria in paragraph 67.

policy_title: Establishing Housing Requirement Figures
summary: Strategic policy-making authorities should establish a housing requirement figure for their whole area, showing how identified housing need (and unmet need from neighbours) can be met over the plan period. This may be higher than identified need due to growth ambitions. Strategic policies should also set a housing requirement for designated neighbourhood areas reflecting the overall strategy. Once adopted, these figures shouldn't need re-testing at neighbourhood plan examination unless significant circumstances change.
cross_references: footnote 32 (Except where a Mayoral, combined authority or high-level joint plan is being prepared...)

policy_title: Indicative Housing Figures for Neighbourhood Areas
summary: Where a housing requirement figure for a neighbourhood area isn't possible (e.g., area designated late, strategic policies outdated), the LPA should provide an indicative figure if requested by the neighbourhood planning body, considering factors like latest local housing need evidence, population, and LPA planning strategy.
cross_references: footnote 33 (Because a neighbourhood area is designated at a late stage...)

policy_title: Benefits of Mixed Tenure Sites
summary: LPAs should support mixed tenure sites through policies and decisions due to their benefits (diverse communities, timely build-out), though this doesn't preclude mainly/entirely Social Rent or other affordable schemes. Mixed tenure can include ownership, rental (Social Rent, other affordable, build to rent), housing for specific groups (older people, students), and custom/self-build plots.

policy_title: Identifying Land for Homes: Strategic Housing Land Availability Assessment (SHLAA)
summary: Strategic policy-making authorities must have a clear understanding of land availability via a SHLAA. From this, planning policies should identify a sufficient supply and mix of sites, considering availability, suitability, and likely economic viability. Policies should identify a supply of specific, deliverable sites for the first 5 years, and specific, developable sites/broad locations for years 6-10 and, where possible, 11-15.
cross_references: footnote 34 (With an appropriate buffer, as set out in paragraph 78a or 78b... See Glossary for definitions...)
targets: specific, deliverable sites for five years
specific, developable sites or broad locations for years 6-10
specific, developable sites or broad locations for years 11-15 (where possible)

policy_title: Promoting Small and Medium Sized Sites
summary: To promote a good mix of sites, LPAs should: a) identify land for at least 10% of housing requirement on sites <=1ha (unless strong reasons prevent it); b) support small sites for community-led/self-build housing; c) use tools like design assessments, PiP, LDOs for small/medium sites; d) support windfall sites within existing settlements.
targets: at least 10% of housing requirement on sites no larger than one hectare

policy_title: Sub-division of Large Sites
summary: Local planning authorities should work with developers to encourage the sub-division of large sites where this could help speed up the delivery of homes.

policy_title: Neighbourhood Planning for Small and Medium-Sized Sites
summary: Neighbourhood planning groups should also give particular consideration to opportunities for allocating small and medium-sized sites (consistent with para 73a) suitable for housing in their area.

policy_title: Windfall Site Allowances
summary: Where an allowance for windfall sites is made in anticipated supply, compelling evidence must show they provide a reliable source. Any allowance must be realistic, considering SHLAA, historic rates, and future trends. Plans should consider policies to resist inappropriate development of residential gardens if it would harm the local area.

policy_title: Exception Sites for Community-Led Development
summary: LPAs should support development of exception sites for community-led development (defined in Annex 2) on sites not otherwise suitable as rural exception sites. These sites should not be allocated for housing and should: a) comprise community-led development with affordable housing (market homes allowed at LPA discretion if essential for delivery); and b) be adjacent to existing settlements, proportionate in size, not compromise protected areas/assets, and comply with local design policies.
cross_references: footnote 35 (This exception site policy does not replace the First Homes exception site policy...)
footnote 36 (Community-led development exception sites should not be larger than one hectare...or exceed 5% of the size of the existing settlement...)
targets: not larger than one hectare (footnote 36)
not exceed 5% of existing settlement size (footnote 36)

policy_title: Planning for Large Scale Development (New Settlements/Extensions)
summary: Large numbers of new homes are often best achieved through larger scale development (new settlements, significant extensions to villages/towns), provided they are well-located, designed, and supported by necessary infrastructure/facilities (including genuine transport choice). Strategic policy-making authorities, with community/other authority support, should identify suitable locations for such development to meet needs sustainably.

policy_title: Considerations for Large Scale Development Locations: Infrastructure and Economy
summary: When identifying locations for large scale development, authorities should consider opportunities from existing/planned infrastructure, area economic potential, and scope for net environmental gains.

policy_title: Considerations for Large Scale Development Locations: Sustainable Communities
summary: When identifying locations for large scale development, authorities should ensure their size and location support a sustainable community, with sufficient access to services and employment, without expecting unrealistic self-containment, or in larger towns with good access.

policy_title: Considerations for Large Scale Development Locations: Quality and Maintenance
summary: When identifying locations for large scale development, authorities should set clear expectations for place quality and maintenance (e.g., Garden City principles), ensuring tools like masterplans and design guides/codes secure well-designed homes for different groups.

policy_title: Considerations for Large Scale Development Locations: Delivery Rates
summary: When identifying locations for large scale development, authorities should make realistic assessments of likely delivery rates (given lead-in times) and identify opportunities for rapid implementation (e.g., joint ventures, locally-led development corporations).
cross_references: footnote 38 (The delivery of large scale developments may need to extend beyond an individual plan period...)

policy_title: Considerations for Large Scale Development Locations: Green Belt
summary: When identifying locations for large scale development, authorities should consider if establishing Green Belt around or adjoining new significant developments is appropriate.

policy_title: Maintaining Housing Supply and Delivery: Trajectory and 5-Year Supply
summary: Strategic policies should include a housing delivery trajectory. LPAs must identify and annually update a supply of specific deliverable sites for a minimum of five years' housing against their housing requirement (from adopted strategic policies, or local housing need if policies are >5 years old). This supply must include a buffer.
cross_references: footnote 38 (Anticipated rates of delivery and infrastructure requirements should... be kept under review...)
footnote 39 (Unless these strategic policies have been reviewed... Where local housing need is used... it should be calculated using the standard method...)
targets: minimum of five years' worth of housing

policy_title: Housing Supply Buffer: Standard
summary: The supply of specific deliverable sites should include a buffer of 5% to ensure choice and competition in the market for land.
targets: 5% buffer

policy_title: Housing Supply Buffer: Significant Under-Delivery
summary: Where there has been significant under-delivery of housing over the previous three years (measured by Housing Delivery Test <85%), the buffer should be 20% to improve prospects of achieving planned supply.
cross_references: footnote 40 (This will be measured against the Housing Delivery Test, where this indicates that delivery was below 85% of the housing requirement.)
targets: 20% buffer
Housing Delivery Test below 85%

policy_title: Housing Supply Buffer: Legacy Plans (Decision-Making Only from July 2026)
summary: From 1 July 2026, for decision-making only, a 20% buffer applies where an LPA has a housing requirement adopted in the last five years examined against a previous NPPF version (or requirement >5 years old but policies reviewed and not needing update), AND whose annual average housing requirement is 80% or less of the most up-to-date local housing need figure (standard method).
cross_references: footnote 41 (Or the housing requirement is more than five years old and the relevant strategic policies have been reviewed and found not to require updating.)
footnote 42 (Defined as the total housing requirement, divided by the number of years in the plan period...)
targets: 20% buffer (from 1 July 2026)
annual average housing requirement is 80% or less of LHN

policy_title: Housing Delivery Test Consequences
summary: If the Housing Delivery Test (HDT) shows delivery below the LPA's housing requirement over the previous three years, specific policy consequences apply.
targets: previous three years (HDT measurement period)

policy_title: HDT Consequence: Delivery Below 95%
summary: Where delivery falls below 95% of the requirement over the previous three years, the authority should prepare an action plan to assess causes of under-delivery and identify actions to increase future delivery.
targets: delivery below 95%

policy_title: HDT Consequence: Delivery Below 85%
summary: Where delivery falls below 85% of the requirement over the previous three years, the authority should include a 20% buffer to their identified supply of specific deliverable sites (as per para 78) and prepare an action plan.
targets: delivery below 85%
20% buffer

policy_title: HDT Consequence: Delivery Below 75%
summary: Where delivery falls below 75% of the requirement over the previous three years, the presumption in favour of sustainable development applies (as per footnote 8), plus requirements for an action plan and 20% buffer.
targets: delivery below 75%
20% buffer

policy_title: Application of Housing Delivery Test Consequences
summary: The Housing Delivery Test consequences apply the day after annual HDT results publication, superseding previous results. Until new results are published, the previously published result should be used.

policy_title: Timely Implementation of Housing Development
summary: To ensure timely implementation of housing proposals, LPAs should consider imposing a planning condition for development to begin within a shorter timescale than the default, if it expedites development without threatening deliverability/viability. For major housing, LPAs should assess why any earlier permission for similar development on the same site did not start.

policy_title: Rural Housing: Responsiveness and Exception Sites
summary: In rural areas, planning policies and decisions should be responsive to local circumstances and support housing developments reflecting local needs, including community-led proposals. LPAs should support opportunities for rural exception sites providing affordable housing for identified local needs, and consider if some market housing would help facilitate this.

policy_title: Location of Housing in Rural Areas
summary: To promote sustainable development in rural areas, housing should be located where it enhances or maintains rural community vitality. Policies should identify opportunities for villages to grow and thrive, especially if supporting local services. Development in one village may support services in a nearby village for groups of smaller settlements.

policy_title: Development of Isolated Homes in the Countryside
summary: Planning policies and decisions should avoid developing isolated homes in the countryside unless specific circumstances apply: essential need for a rural worker; optimal viable use of a heritage asset or enabling development; re-use of redundant/disused buildings enhancing setting; subdivision of existing residential building; or design of exceptional quality (truly outstanding architecture raising rural design standards AND significantly enhancing immediate setting and sensitive to local characteristics).

policy_title: Creating Conditions for Business Investment and Growth
summary: Planning policies and decisions should help create conditions for businesses to invest, expand, and adapt. Significant weight should be placed on supporting economic growth and productivity, considering local business needs and wider development opportunities, allowing areas to build on strengths, counter weaknesses, and address future challenges, especially in areas of innovation and high productivity.

policy_title: Planning Policies for Economic Growth
summary: Outlines requirements for planning policies related to economic growth, including setting a clear economic vision, identifying sites for investment, facilitating modern economy needs, addressing investment barriers, and being flexible to new needs and working practices.

policy_title: Economic Vision and Strategy
summary: Planning policies should set out a clear economic vision and strategy that positively and proactively encourages sustainable economic growth, considering the national industrial strategy, Local Industrial Strategies, and other local economic development policies.
cross_references: footnote 43 (Invest 2035: The UK's Modern Industrial Strategy identifies priority sectors...)

policy_title: Identifying Sites for Investment
summary: Planning policies should set criteria and identify strategic sites for local and inward investment that match the economic strategy and meet anticipated needs over the plan period.

policy_title: Facilitating Modern Economy Needs
summary: Planning policies should pay particular regard to facilitating development for a modern economy, including identifying suitable locations for uses like laboratories, gigafactories, data centres, digital infrastructure, freight, and logistics.

policy_title: Addressing Barriers to Investment
summary: Planning policies should seek to address potential barriers to investment, such as inadequate infrastructure, services or housing, or a poor environment.

policy_title: Flexibility for Unanticipated Needs and Working Practices
summary: Planning policies should be flexible enough to accommodate needs not anticipated in the plan and allow for new and flexible working practices and spaces to enable a rapid response to changing economic circumstances.

policy_title: Locational Requirements of Different Sectors
summary: Planning policies and decisions should recognise and address specific locational requirements of different sectors, including providing for knowledge/data-driven/creative/high-tech industry clusters, storage/distribution operations, and expansion/modernisation of other key local/regional/national industries.

policy_title: Provision for Knowledge, Data-Driven, Creative or High Technology Industries
summary: Planning policies should make provision for clusters or networks of knowledge and data-driven, creative or high technology industries, and for new, expanded or upgraded facilities and infrastructure (including data centres and grid connections) supporting their growth.

policy_title: Provision for Storage and Distribution Operations
summary: Planning policies should make provision for storage and distribution operations at various scales in suitably accessible locations that allow efficient and reliable goods handling, especially where needed for supply chain, transport innovation, and decarbonisation.

policy_title: Provision for Expansion/Modernisation of Other Key Industries
summary: Planning policies should make provision for the expansion or modernisation of other industries of local, regional, or national importance to support economic growth and resilience.

policy_title: Supporting a Prosperous Rural Economy
summary: Planning policies and decisions should enable: sustainable growth/expansion of all rural businesses (new build and conversions); development/diversification of agricultural/land-based businesses; sustainable rural tourism/leisure respecting countryside character; and retention/development of accessible local services/community facilities.

policy_title: Site Location for Rural Business and Community Needs
summary: Recognises that sites for local business/community needs in rural areas may need to be adjacent to or beyond existing settlements, and in locations not well served by public transport. Development should be sensitive to surroundings, not unacceptably impact local roads, and exploit opportunities for sustainability (e.g., improving foot/cycle/public transport access). Use of previously developed land and sites well-related to existing settlements should be encouraged.

policy_title: Ensuring the Vitality of Town Centres: General Approach
summary: Planning policies and decisions should support the role of town centres at the heart of local communities by taking a positive approach to their growth, management, and adaptation.

policy_title: Defining Network and Hierarchy of Town Centres
summary: Planning policies should define a network and hierarchy of town centres and promote their long-term vitality and viability by allowing them to grow and diversify in response to retail/leisure changes, permitting a suitable mix of uses (including housing), and reflecting their distinctive characters.

policy_title: Defining Extent of Town Centres and Primary Shopping Areas
summary: Planning policies should define the extent of town centres and primary shopping areas, and clarify the range of uses permitted in such locations as part of a positive strategy for each centre's future.

policy_title: Retaining and Enhancing Markets
summary: Planning policies should retain and enhance existing markets and, where appropriate, re-introduce or create new ones.

policy_title: Allocating Sites in Town Centres
summary: Planning policies should allocate a range of suitable sites in town centres to meet the scale and type of likely needed development, looking at least ten years ahead. Meeting anticipated needs for retail, leisure, office, and other main town centre uses should not be compromised by limited site availability; town centre boundaries should be reviewed where necessary.
targets: at least ten years ahead (site allocation horizon)

policy_title: Allocating Edge of Centre Sites
summary: Where suitable and viable town centre sites are unavailable for main town centre uses, planning policies should allocate appropriate edge of centre sites well connected to the town centre. If sufficient edge of centre sites cannot be identified, policies should explain how needs can be met in other accessible, well-connected locations.

policy_title: Residential Development in Town Centres
summary: Planning policies should recognise that residential development often plays an important role in ensuring centre vitality and encourage residential development on appropriate sites.

policy_title: Sequential Test for Main Town Centre Uses Not in Centres or Plan
summary: LPAs should apply a sequential test to applications for main town centre uses neither in an existing centre nor in accordance with an up-to-date plan. Main town centre uses should be in town centres, then edge of centre locations; only if suitable sites are unavailable (or not expected to be soon) should out of centre sites be considered.

policy_title: Considering Edge and Out of Centre Proposals: Accessibility and Flexibility
summary: When considering edge of centre and out of centre proposals, preference should be given to accessible sites well connected to the town centre. Applicants and LPAs should demonstrate flexibility on issues like format and scale to fully explore opportunities on suitable town centre or edge of centre sites.

policy_title: Exemption from Sequential Approach for Small Scale Rural Development
summary: The sequential approach (in paras 91-92) should not be applied to applications for small scale rural offices or other small scale rural development.

policy_title: Impact Assessment for Out-of-Centre Retail and Leisure Development
summary: When assessing applications for retail and leisure development outside town centres and not in accordance with an up-to-date plan, LPAs should require an impact assessment if the development exceeds a proportionate, locally set floorspace threshold (default 2,500m² gross). This should assess impact on existing/committed/planned investment and on town centre vitality/viability.
targets: 2,500m² gross floorspace (default threshold)

policy_title: Refusal for Failing Sequential Test or Significant Adverse Impact
summary: Where an application fails to satisfy the sequential test or is likely to have significant adverse impact on considerations in paragraph 94 (investment, vitality/viability), it should be refused.

policy_title: Achieving Healthy, Inclusive and Safe Places
summary: Planning policies and decisions should aim to achieve healthy, inclusive, and safe places which promote social interaction, are safe and accessible (not undermining quality of life/community cohesion by crime/fear of crime), and enable/support healthy lives (addressing health needs/inequalities).

policy_title: Refusing Applications for Hot Food Takeaways and Fast Food Outlets
summary: LPAs should refuse applications for hot food takeaways and fast food outlets: a) within walking distance of schools/places children congregate (unless in a designated town centre); or b) in locations where evidence shows a concentration of such uses adversely impacts local health, pollution, or anti-social behaviour.

policy_title: Providing Social, Recreational and Cultural Facilities and Services
summary: Planning policies and decisions should: plan positively for shared spaces and community facilities; support local health/social/cultural well-being strategies; guard against unnecessary loss of valued facilities; ensure established facilities can develop/modernise; and ensure an integrated approach to locating housing, economic uses, and community facilities.

policy_title: Estate Regeneration
summary: Planning policies and decisions should consider the social, economic, and environmental benefits of estate regeneration. LPAs should use their planning powers to help deliver high-standard estate regeneration.

policy_title: Sufficient Choice of Early Years, School and Post-16 Places
summary: A sufficient choice of early years, school, and post-16 places must be available for existing and new communities. LPAs should be proactive, positive, and collaborative in meeting this requirement and widening educational choice. They should give great weight to creating/expanding/altering such facilities and work with promoters/partners to resolve key planning issues pre-application.

policy_title: Faster Delivery of Other Public Service Infrastructure
summary: To ensure faster delivery of other public service infrastructure (health, blue light, library, adult education, university, criminal justice facilities), LPAs should work proactively and positively with promoters/partners to plan for required facilities and resolve key planning issues pre-application. Significant weight should be placed on new/expanded/upgraded public service infrastructure proposals.

policy_title: Promoting Public Safety and Security Requirements
summary: Planning policies and decisions should promote public safety and consider wider security/defence requirements by anticipating/addressing malicious threats and hazards (using up-to-date police/agency information to reduce vulnerability and ensure safety, including child safety near hazards), and recognising/supporting development for operational defence/security purposes while ensuring operational sites are not adversely affected by other development.
cross_references: footnote 44 (This includes transport hubs, night-time economy venues, cinemas and theatres, sports stadia and arenas, shopping centres, health and education establishments, places of worship, hotels and restaurants, visitor attractions and commercial centres.)

policy_title: Open Space and Recreation: Needs Assessment
summary: Access to high-quality open spaces and sport/physical activity opportunities is important for health, well-being, nature benefits, and climate change efforts. Planning policies should be based on robust, up-to-date assessments of need for open space, sport, and recreation facilities (including deficits/surpluses) and new provision opportunities. Assessment information should determine what provision is needed and accommodated in plans.

policy_title: Protection of Existing Open Space, Sports and Recreational Buildings and Land
summary: Existing open space, sports and recreational buildings/land (including playing fields, formal play spaces) should not be built on unless: an assessment shows it's surplus; the loss would be replaced by equivalent or better provision suitably located; or the development is for alternative sports/recreational provision whose benefits clearly outweigh the loss.

policy_title: Protecting and Enhancing Public Rights of Way and Access
summary: Planning policies and decisions should protect and enhance public rights of way and access, including taking opportunities to provide better user facilities (e.g., adding links to existing networks including National Trails).

policy_title: Designating Local Green Space
summary: Designation of Local Green Space through local/neighbourhood plans allows communities to identify and protect locally important green areas. This should be consistent with local sustainable development planning, complement investment in homes/jobs/services, be designated only when a plan is prepared/updated, and be capable of enduring beyond the plan period.

policy_title: Criteria for Local Green Space Designation
summary: Local Green Space designation should only be used where the green space is: in reasonably close proximity to the community it serves; demonstrably special to a local community with particular local significance (e.g., beauty, historic significance, recreational value, tranquillity, wildlife richness); and local in character, not an extensive tract of land.

policy_title: Managing Development within Local Green Space
summary: Policies and decisions for managing development within a Local Green Space should be consistent with national policy for Green Belts (set out in chapter 13), excluding provisions for grey belt and previously developed land.
cross_references: footnote 45 (Excluding provisions relating to grey belt and previously developed land set out in chapter 13.)

policy_title: Consideration of Transport Issues in Plan-Making and Development Proposals
summary: Transport issues should be considered from the earliest stages of plan-making and development proposals using a vision-led approach to identify solutions for well-designed, sustainable, popular places. This involves early community engagement, integrating movement/streets/parking into design, understanding/addressing transport network impacts, realising opportunities from existing/proposed infrastructure and changing technology, promoting walking/cycling/public transport, and identifying/assessing/mitigating environmental impacts of traffic/transport infrastructure.

policy_title: Managing Patterns of Growth for Sustainable Transport
summary: The planning system should actively manage growth patterns to support sustainable transport objectives. Significant development should be focused on locations that are or can be made sustainable by limiting travel need and offering genuine transport mode choices. This helps reduce congestion/emissions and improve air quality/public health. Opportunities for sustainable transport solutions vary between urban/rural areas and should be considered in plan-making and decision-making.

policy_title: Content of Planning Policies for Sustainable Transport
summary: Outlines specific requirements for planning policies related to sustainable transport, including supporting appropriate land use mix, active involvement of transport authorities, and identifying/protecting sites/routes for future transport infrastructure.

policy_title: Supporting Appropriate Mix of Uses
summary: Planning policies should support an appropriate mix of uses across an area, and within larger scale sites, to minimise the number and length of journeys for employment, shopping, leisure, education, and other activities.

policy_title: Involvement of Transport Authorities in Plan Preparation
summary: Planning policies should be prepared with the active involvement of local highways authorities, other transport infrastructure providers/operators, and neighbouring councils, so strategies and investments for sustainable transport and development patterns are aligned.

policy_title: Identifying and Protecting Sites for Transport Infrastructure
summary: Planning policies should identify and protect, where robust evidence exists, sites and routes critical for developing infrastructure to widen transport choice and realise opportunities for large scale development.

policy_title: Providing for Walking and Cycling Networks
summary: Planning policies should provide for attractive and well-designed walking and cycling networks with supporting facilities like secure cycle parking, drawing on Local Cycling and Walking Infrastructure Plans (LCWIPs).
cross_references: Local Cycling and Walking Infrastructure Plans

policy_title: Providing for Large Scale Transport Facilities
summary: Planning policies should provide for any large scale transport facilities needed in the area, and the supporting infrastructure/wider development for their operation, expansion, and contribution to the wider economy. This should consider if such development is a nationally significant infrastructure project (NSIP) and any relevant national policy statements.
cross_references: footnote 46 (Policies for large scale facilities should, where necessary, be developed through collaboration... Examples include ports, airports, interchanges for rail freight, public transport projects and roadside services...)

policy_title: Recognising the Importance of General Aviation Airfields
summary: Planning policies should recognise the importance of maintaining a national network of general aviation airfields and their need to adapt/change over time, considering their economic value for business, leisure, training, emergency services, and the General Aviation Strategy.
cross_references: footnote 47 (Department for Transport (2015) General Aviation Strategy.)

policy_title: Setting Local Parking Standards
summary: If setting local parking standards for residential and non-residential development, policies should consider: development accessibility; type, mix and use of development; public transport availability/opportunities; local car ownership levels; and the need for adequate electric vehicle charging spaces.

policy_title: Maximum Parking Standards and Town Centre Parking Quality
summary: Maximum parking standards for residential and non-residential development should only be set with clear and compelling justification for managing the local road network or optimising development density in well-served city/town centres and other locations (per Chapter 11). In town centres, LPAs should aim to improve parking quality (convenience, safety, security) alongside measures promoting pedestrian/cyclist accessibility.

policy_title: Overnight Lorry Parking Facilities
summary: Planning policies and decisions should recognise the importance of providing adequate overnight lorry parking facilities, considering local shortages, to reduce risks of parking in unsuitable locations. Proposals for new/expanded distribution centres should provide sufficient lorry parking for anticipated use.

policy_title: Assessing Sites for Development: Transport Considerations
summary: When assessing sites for allocation or specific applications, it should be ensured that: sustainable transport modes are prioritised; safe and suitable access for all users is achievable; design of streets/parking/etc. reflects national guidance (National Design Guide, National Model Design Code); and significant transport network/highway safety impacts can be cost-effectively mitigated to an acceptable degree through a vision-led approach.
cross_references: footnote 48 (Policies and decisions should not make use of or reflect the former Design Bulletin 32, which was withdrawn in 2007.)

policy_title: Refusal on Highways Grounds
summary: Development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or if residual cumulative impacts on the road network, after mitigation, would be severe, considering all reasonable future scenarios.

policy_title: Priorities and Design for Development Applications (Transport Context)
summary: Within the context of assessing development applications, they should: prioritise pedestrian/cycle movements; facilitate access to high-quality public transport; address needs of people with disabilities/reduced mobility; create safe, secure, attractive places minimising pedestrian/cyclist/vehicle conflicts and street clutter; allow efficient goods delivery and emergency access; and be designed for EV charging.

policy_title: Travel Plans and Transport Assessments/Statements for Significant Movement Generating Development
summary: All developments generating significant movement should be required to provide a travel plan. The application should be supported by a vision-led transport statement or transport assessment so likely impacts can be assessed and monitored.

policy_title: Supporting High Quality Communications Infrastructure
summary: Advanced, high-quality, reliable communications infrastructure is essential for economic growth and social well-being. Planning policies and decisions should support expansion of electronic communications networks (including 5G, full fibre broadband). Policies should set out how high-quality digital infrastructure providing access from various providers is expected to be delivered/upgraded, prioritising full fibre connections to existing/new developments as the optimum solution in almost all cases.

policy_title: Minimising Radio and Electronic Communications Masts and Sites
summary: The number of radio/electronic communications masts and sites should be kept to a minimum consistent with consumer needs, efficient network operation, and reasonable future expansion capacity. Use of existing masts/buildings/structures for new capability (including wireless) should be encouraged. New sites (e.g., for 5G, connected transport, smart cities) should have sympathetically designed and camouflaged equipment where appropriate.

policy_title: Restrictions on Local Planning Authorities Regarding Communications Development
summary: LPAs should not impose bans on new electronic communications development in certain areas, blanket Article 4 directions over wide areas/ranges of development, or insist on minimum distances between new and existing development. They must ensure they have evidence that infrastructure is not expected to cause significant/irremediable interference with other electrical equipment/air traffic services/instrumentation in national interest, and have considered interference from new buildings with broadcast/electronic communications.

policy_title: Evidence Supporting Applications for Electronic Communications Development
summary: Applications for electronic communications development (including prior approval under GPDO) must be supported by necessary evidence to justify it. This includes consultation outcomes (especially near schools/colleges or safeguarding zones) and, for additions to existing masts/stations, a self-certification of non-exceedance of ICNIRP guidelines on cumulative exposure.
geographic_mentions: military explosives storage area safeguarding zone

policy_title: Evidence for New Masts or Base Stations
summary: For a new mast or base station, evidence should show the applicant explored erecting antennas on existing structures and include a self-certification that ICNIRP guidelines will be met when operational.

policy_title: Determining Communications Applications on Planning Grounds Only
summary: LPAs must determine applications for electronic communications on planning grounds only. They should not prevent competition, question the need for the system, or set health safeguards different from ICNIRP guidelines for public exposure.

policy_title: Promoting Effective Use of Land
summary: Planning policies and decisions should promote effective land use in meeting needs for homes and other uses, while safeguarding/improving the environment and ensuring safe/healthy living conditions. Strategic policies should set a clear strategy for accommodating objectively assessed needs, making as much use as possible of previously-developed or 'brownfield' land.
cross_references: footnote 49 (Except where this would conflict with other policies in this Framework, including causing harm to designated sites of importance for biodiversity.)

policy_title: Principles for Effective Land Use in Policies and Decisions
summary: Outlines principles for planning policies and decisions regarding effective land use: encouraging multiple benefits from urban/rural land; recognising functions of undeveloped land; giving substantial weight to using suitable brownfield land; promoting development of under-utilised land/buildings; and supporting use of airspace above existing premises.

policy_title: Encouraging Multiple Benefits from Land
summary: Planning policies and decisions should encourage multiple benefits from both urban and rural land, including through mixed-use schemes and taking opportunities for net environmental gains (e.g., developments enabling new habitat creation or improved public access to countryside).

policy_title: Recognising Functions of Undeveloped Land
summary: Planning policies and decisions should recognise that some undeveloped land can perform many functions, such as for wildlife, recreation, flood risk mitigation, cooling/shading, carbon storage, or food production.

policy_title: Using Suitable Brownfield Land
summary: Planning policies and decisions should give substantial weight to the value of using suitable brownfield land within settlements for homes and other identified needs. Proposals should be approved unless substantial harm would be caused. Support appropriate opportunities to remediate despoiled, degraded, derelict, contaminated, or unstable land.

policy_title: Development of Under-Utilised Land and Buildings
summary: Planning policies and decisions should promote and support the development of under-utilised land and buildings, especially if it helps meet identified housing needs where land supply is constrained and sites could be used more effectively (e.g., converting space above shops, building on/above service yards, car parks, lock-ups, railway infrastructure).
cross_references: footnote 50 (As part of this approach, plans and decisions should support efforts to identify and bring back into residential use empty homes and other buildings, supported by the use of compulsory purchase powers where appropriate.)

policy_title: Using Airspace Above Existing Premises (Upward Extensions)
summary: Planning policies and decisions should support opportunities to use airspace above existing residential/commercial premises for new homes. They should allow upward extensions (including mansard roofs) where development is consistent with prevailing form/street scene, well-designed (complying with local design policies/standards), and maintains safe access/egress. Conditions for simultaneous development of multiple upward extensions require exceptional justification.

policy_title: Proactive Role in Identifying and Bringing Forward Land
summary: LPAs and other plan-making bodies should be proactive in identifying and helping bring forward land suitable for meeting development needs, including sites on brownfield registers or in public ownership, using their full powers (e.g., to facilitate land assembly, supported by CPO where necessary).

policy_title: Reflecting Changes in Demand for Land
summary: Planning policies and decisions must reflect changes in land demand, informed by regular reviews of allocated land and land availability. Where no reasonable prospect of an allocated use coming forward exists, LPAs should (via plan updates) reallocate for a more deliverable use addressing identified needs (or deallocate if undeveloped). In the interim, applications for alternative uses meeting unmet needs should be supported.

policy_title: Positive Approach to Alternative Uses of Developed Land
summary: LPAs should take a positive approach to applications for alternative uses of currently developed land not allocated for a specific purpose in plans, where this would help meet identified development needs. This includes supporting use of retail/employment land for homes in high housing demand areas (if not undermining key economic sectors/sites or town centre vitality, and compatible with other policies), and more effective use of community service sites (schools, hospitals) if service quality/access to open space is maintained/improved.

policy_title: Achieving Appropriate Densities: Considerations
summary: Planning policies and decisions should support development making efficient land use, considering: identified need for different housing/development types and land availability; local market conditions/viability; infrastructure/service availability/capacity and potential for improvement/sustainable travel; desirability of maintaining area character/setting (including residential gardens) or promoting regeneration/change; and importance of securing well-designed, attractive, healthy places.

policy_title: Using Design Tools and Optimising Land Use in Shortage Areas
summary: Area-based character assessments, design guides/codes, and masterplans can help ensure efficient land use while creating beautiful, sustainable places. Where land shortages for housing exist, it's especially important policies/decisions avoid low-density homes and ensure optimal site potential use.

policy_title: Optimising Land Use: Minimum Density Standards
summary: In land shortage circumstances, plans should contain policies to optimise land use and meet as much identified housing need as possible (tested robustly at examination). This should include using minimum density standards for city/town centres and other locations well-served by public transport, seeking significant uplift in average residential density in these areas unless strong reasons make it inappropriate.
targets: significant uplift in average density

policy_title: Minimum Density Standards in Other Plan Areas
summary: In land shortage circumstances, using minimum density standards should also be considered for other parts of the plan area. A range of densities reflecting accessibility and potential of different areas may be appropriate, rather than one broad density range.

policy_title: Refusing Inefficient Land Use and Flexibility on Daylight/Sunlight
summary: In land shortage circumstances, LPAs should refuse applications failing to make efficient land use (considering NPPF policies). For housing applications, authorities should be flexible in applying daylight/sunlight policies/guidance where they'd otherwise inhibit efficient site use, provided the scheme offers acceptable living standards.

policy_title: Fundamental Role of Good Design
summary: Creating high quality, beautiful, sustainable buildings and places is fundamental to planning. Good design is key to sustainable development, creating better places to live/work, and making development acceptable to communities. Clarity on design expectations and testing methods is essential, as is effective engagement between applicants, communities, LPAs, and other interests.

policy_title: Design Vision and Expectations in Plans
summary: Plans (at the most appropriate level) should set a clear design vision and expectations for applicant certainty. Design policies should be developed with local communities to reflect local aspirations, grounded in understanding/evaluating area defining characteristics. Neighbourhood planning groups play an important role in identifying special qualities and reflecting them in development via their plans or engagement in LPA/developer design policy/guidance/code production.

policy_title: Preparation of Design Guides and Codes by LPAs
summary: For maximum clarity on early-stage design expectations, all LPAs should prepare design guides or codes consistent with National Design Guide/National Model Design Code principles, reflecting local character and design preferences. These provide a local framework for beautiful, distinctive, high-quality places. Coverage, detail, and prescription should be tailored to local circumstances/scale of change, allowing suitable variety.

policy_title: Scope and Status of Design Guides and Codes
summary: Design guides/codes can be area-wide, neighbourhood, or site-specific. To carry weight in decision-making, they should be part of a plan or SPDs. Landowners/developers can contribute or prepare their own. All guides/codes must be based on effective community engagement, reflect local aspirations, and consider national guidance (NDG, NMDC). National documents guide decisions if local guides/codes are absent.

policy_title: Ensuring Quality Development: Core Design Principles
summary: Planning policies and decisions should ensure developments: function well and add to area quality long-term; are visually attractive (good architecture, layout, landscaping); are sympathetic to local character/history (while not preventing innovation); establish/maintain a strong sense of place; optimise site potential for development mix and support local facilities/transport; and create safe, inclusive, accessible places promoting health/well-being with high amenity, where crime/disorder don't undermine quality of life.
