policy_title: Trees in Urban Environments
summary: Trees significantly contribute to urban environment character/quality and climate mitigation/adaptation. Planning policies/decisions should ensure new streets are tree-lined; opportunities to incorporate trees elsewhere (parks, community orchards) are taken; measures for long-term maintenance of new trees are in place; and existing trees are retained wherever possible. Applicants/LPAs should work with highways/tree officers for right trees in right places, compatible with highway standards/user needs.
cross_references: footnote 52 (Unless, in specific cases, there are clear, justifiable and compelling reasons why this would be inappropriate.)

policy_title: Evolution and Assessment of Design Quality
summary: Design quality should be considered throughout proposal evolution/assessment. Early discussion between applicants, LPA, and local community on design/style of emerging schemes is important for clarifying expectations and reconciling interests. Applicants should provide sufficient information to demonstrate how proposals meet local/national design expectations and work closely with affected parties to evolve designs based on community views. Applications demonstrating early, proactive, effective community engagement should be looked on more favourably.

policy_title: Tools and Processes for Assessing and Improving Design
summary: LPAs should ensure access to and appropriate use of tools/processes for assessing/improving development design. The National Model Design Code is primary basis for local design codes. Assessment tools include community engagement workshops, design advice/review arrangements, and frameworks like Building for a Healthy Life. These are most beneficial if used early, especially for significant projects. Outcomes from these processes, including design review panel recommendations, should be regarded in assessing applications.
cross_references: footnote 53 (Birkbeck D and Kruczkowski S et al (2020) Building for a Healthy Life.)

policy_title: Decision-Making on Design Quality
summary: Poorly designed development should be refused, especially if failing to reflect local design policies and government guidance (considering local design guidance/SPDs). Conversely, significant weight should be given to development reflecting local/government design guidance/policies AND/OR outstanding/innovative designs promoting high sustainability or raising area design standards, if fitting overall form/layout.
cross_references: footnote 54 (Contained in the National Design Guide and National Model Design Code.)

policy_title: Clarity in Planning Conditions and Maintaining Approved Quality
summary: LPAs should ensure relevant planning conditions refer to clear, accurate plans/drawings providing visual clarity on development design and approved materials. This provides certainty for implementers and a basis for identifying breaches. LPAs should also seek to ensure approved development quality isn't materially diminished between permission and completion due to changes in the permitted scheme (e.g., approved details like materials).

policy_title: Control of Advertisements
summary: Poorly sited/designed advertisements can harm place quality/character. A separate consent process controls advertisement display, operated simply, efficiently, and effectively. Advertisements should be controlled only for amenity and public safety, considering cumulative impacts.

policy_title: Importance and Aim of Green Belts
summary: The Government attaches great importance to Green Belts. Their fundamental aim is to prevent urban sprawl by keeping land permanently open. The essential characteristics of Green Belts are their openness and permanence.

policy_title: Purposes of Green Belt
summary: Green Belt serves five purposes: to check unrestricted sprawl of large built-up areas; to prevent neighbouring towns merging; to assist in safeguarding the countryside from encroachment; to preserve the setting and special character of historic towns; and to assist in urban regeneration by encouraging recycling of derelict and other urban land.

policy_title: Establishing New Green Belts
summary: The general extent of Green Belts is already established. New Green Belts should only be established in exceptional circumstances (e.g., for new settlements or major urban extensions). Proposals for new Green Belts must be set out in strategic policies and demonstrate why normal policies are inadequate, if major changes in circumstances necessitate it, the consequences for sustainable development, the necessity and consistency with adjoining area policies, and how it meets other Framework objectives.

policy_title: Altering Green Belt Boundaries
summary: Once established, Green Belt boundaries should only be altered where exceptional circumstances are fully evidenced and justified through plan preparation or updates. Strategic policies should establish the need for any changes, considering their long-term permanence. Detailed amendments can be made through non-strategic policies, including neighbourhood plans.

policy_title: Exceptional Circumstances for Green Belt Boundary Review (Unmet Need)
summary: Exceptional circumstances for altering Green Belt boundaries include instances where an authority cannot meet its identified need for homes, commercial, or other development through other means. If so, authorities should review Green Belt boundaries per NPPF policies and propose alterations to meet these needs in full, unless the review clearly shows this would fundamentally undermine the remaining Green Belt's purposes across the plan area.

policy_title: Demonstrating No Reasonable Alternatives Before Altering Green Belt Boundaries
summary: Before concluding exceptional circumstances exist to justify Green Belt boundary changes, the strategic policy-making authority must demonstrate it has fully examined all other reasonable options for meeting identified development need. This is assessed via strategic policy examination, considering preceding paragraph (146) and whether the strategy: makes maximum use of suitable brownfield/underutilised land; optimises density per Chapter 11 (including significant uplift in minimum density standards in accessible locations); and has been informed by discussions with neighbouring authorities about accommodating need (evidenced by statement of common ground).

policy_title: Prioritising Land for Release from Green Belt and Sustainable Development Patterns
summary: When releasing Green Belt land for development, plans should prioritise previously developed land, then consider grey belt not previously developed, then other Green Belt locations. However, when drawing up/reviewing boundaries, the need to promote sustainable development patterns should determine site location appropriateness (referencing paras 110 & 115). Authorities should consider consequences of channelling development towards urban areas within the Green Belt, inset towns/villages, or locations beyond the outer boundary.

policy_title: Criteria for Defining Green Belt Boundaries
summary: When defining Green Belt boundaries, plans should: ensure consistency with development plan strategy for meeting identified sustainable development requirements; not include land unnecessary to keep permanently open; where necessary, identify safeguarded land between urban area and Green Belt for longer-term needs (not allocated for current development); demonstrate boundaries won't need altering at plan period end; and define boundaries clearly using readily recognisable, likely permanent physical features.

policy_title: Including Villages in the Green Belt
summary: If restricting development in a village is necessary primarily due to its open character's contribution to Green Belt openness, the village should be included in the Green Belt. If village character needs protection for other reasons, other means (conservation area, normal development management policies) should be used, and the village excluded from the Green Belt.

policy_title: Enhancing Beneficial Use of Green Belts and Applying 'Golden Rules'
summary: Once Green Belts are defined, LPAs should plan positively to enhance their beneficial use (e.g., access, outdoor sport/recreation, retaining/enhancing landscapes, visual amenity, biodiversity, improving damaged/derelict land). Where Green Belt land is released for development via plan preparation/review, 'Golden Rules' in paragraph 156 apply.

policy_title: National Forest and Community Forests in the Green Belt
summary: The National Forest and Community Forests offer valuable opportunities for environmental improvement around towns/cities (upgrading landscape, recreation, wildlife). The National Forest Strategy and approved Community Forest Plans can be material considerations. Development proposals within these areas in the Green Belt are subject to normal Green Belt control policies.

policy_title: Considering Proposals Affecting the Green Belt: Harm and Very Special Circumstances
summary: When considering any planning application, LPAs should ensure substantial weight is given to any harm to the Green Belt, including harm to its openness. Inappropriate development is, by definition, harmful and should not be approved except in very special circumstances. 'Very special circumstances' will not exist unless potential harm (by inappropriateness and any other harm) is clearly outweighed by other considerations.
cross_references: footnote 55 (Other than in the case of development on previously developed land or grey belt land, where development is not inappropriate.)

policy_title: Exceptions to Inappropriate Development in the Green Belt
summary: Lists forms of development that are not inappropriate in the Green Belt, provided they preserve openness and do not conflict with Green Belt purposes.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Buildings for Agriculture and Forestry
summary: Buildings for agriculture and forestry are an exception to inappropriate development in the Green Belt.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Facilities for Outdoor Sport, Recreation, Cemeteries, Allotments
summary: Provision of appropriate facilities (including buildings) for outdoor sport, outdoor recreation, cemeteries and burial grounds, and allotments is an exception to inappropriate development in the Green Belt, as long as facilities preserve openness and don't conflict with Green Belt purposes.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Extension or Alteration of a Building
summary: The extension or alteration of a building is an exception to inappropriate development in the Green Belt, provided it does not result in disproportionate additions over and above the size of the original building.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Replacement of a Building
summary: The replacement of a building is an exception to inappropriate development in the Green Belt, provided the new building is in the same use and not materially larger than the one it replaces.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Limited Infilling in Villages
summary: Limited infilling in villages is an exception to inappropriate development in the Green Belt.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Limited Affordable Housing for Local Community Needs
summary: Limited affordable housing for local community needs under policies set out in the development plan (including policies for rural exception sites) is an exception to inappropriate development in the Green Belt.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Limited Infilling/Redevelopment of Previously Developed Land (PDL)
summary: Limited infilling or partial/complete redevelopment of previously developed land (including material change of use to residential or mixed-use including residential), whether redundant or in continuing use (excluding temporary buildings), which would not cause substantial harm to Green Belt openness, is an exception to inappropriate development.

policy_title: Green Belt Exception: Other Forms of Development Preserving Openness
summary: Other forms of development are exceptions to inappropriate development in the Green Belt provided they preserve its openness and do not conflict with its purposes. These include: mineral extraction; engineering operations; local transport infrastructure with demonstrated Green Belt location need; re-use of permanent, substantial buildings; material changes of land use (e.g., outdoor sport, cemeteries); and development under Community Right to Build/Neighbourhood Development Orders.

policy_title: Homes, Commercial and Other Development in the Green Belt Not Regarded as Inappropriate (Specific Criteria)
summary: Development of homes, commercial, and other development in the Green Belt should also not be regarded as inappropriate where all specified conditions apply: it would utilise grey belt land and not fundamentally undermine remaining Green Belt purposes; there's demonstrable unmet need for the development type; it's in a sustainable location (referencing paras 110 & 115); and where applicable, it meets 'Golden Rules' (paras 156-157).
cross_references: footnote 56 (Which, in the case of applications involving the provision of housing, means the lack of a five year supply... or where the Housing Delivery Tests was below 75%...; and in the case of traveller sites means the lack of a five year supply...)
footnote 57 (In the case of development involving the provision of traveller sites, particular reference should be made to Planning Policy for Traveller Sites paragraph 13.)
targets: lack of a five year supply of deliverable housing sites (footnote 56)
Housing Delivery Test below 75% (footnote 56)
lack of a five year supply of deliverable traveller sites (footnote 56)

policy_title: 'Golden Rules' Contributions for Major Housing in/Released from Green Belt
summary: Where major housing development is proposed on land released from Green Belt via plan review, or on Green Belt sites via planning application, specific 'Golden Rules' contributions should be made: affordable housing (per para 67-68 or 157); necessary local/national infrastructure improvements; and provision of new/improved public green spaces accessible within a short walk (on-site or off-site).
cross_references: footnote 58 (The Golden Rules do not apply to: (i) developments brought forward on land released from the Green Belt through plans that were adopted prior to the publication of this Framework; and (ii) developments that were granted planning permission on Green Belt land prior to the publication of this Framework.)
footnote 59 (Including where there are variations made to existing permissions (where the existing permission involved development that was subject to the Golden Rules).)

policy_title: Affordable Housing Contribution Level for 'Golden Rules'
summary: Before development plan affordable housing policies are updated (per paras 67-68), the affordable housing contribution for the Golden Rules is 15 percentage points above the highest existing applicable requirement, capped at 50%. If no pre-existing requirement, 50% applies by default. Site-specific viability assessment for land in/released from Green Belt follows national planning practice guidance.
cross_references: footnote 60 (The 50% cap does not apply to rural exception sites or community-led development exception sites, or if the local planning authority has a relevant existing policy which would apply to the development which is above 50%.)
targets: 15 percentage points above existing affordable housing requirement
50% cap on affordable housing
50% default affordable housing

policy_title: Weight for Development Complying with Golden Rules
summary: A development complying with the Golden Rules should be given significant weight in favour of granting permission.

policy_title: Green Space Improvements under Golden Rules
summary: Green space improvements required by Golden Rules should positively contribute to development landscape setting, support nature recovery, and meet local green space standards (if existing in development plan). If no local standards, national standards (e.g., Natural England accessible green space, urban greening factor, Green Flag criteria) apply. Where land is identified in Local Nature Recovery Strategies for habitat creation/nature recovery, proposals should contribute to these outcomes.

policy_title: Renewable Energy Projects in the Green Belt
summary: When located in the Green Belt, elements of many renewable energy projects will comprise inappropriate development. Developers must demonstrate very special circumstances for projects to proceed, which may include wider environmental benefits from increased renewable energy production.

policy_title: Planning System's Role in Addressing Climate Change
summary: The planning system should support the transition to net zero by 2050 and fully account for all climate impacts (overheating, water scarcity, storm/flood risks, coastal change). It should help shape places to achieve radical greenhouse gas emission reductions, minimise vulnerability, improve resilience, encourage reuse of existing resources (including building conversion), and support renewable/low carbon energy and associated infrastructure.
targets: net zero by 2050

policy_title: Proactive Approach to Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation in Plans
summary: Plans should take a proactive approach to mitigating and adapting to climate change, considering long-term implications for flood risk, coastal change, water supply, biodiversity, landscapes, and overheating/drought risk from rising temperatures. Policies should support measures for future health/resilience of communities/infrastructure (e.g., space for physical protection, provision for future relocation of vulnerable development/infrastructure).
cross_references: footnote 61 (In line with the objectives and provisions of the Climate Change Act 2008.)

policy_title: Considering Climate Change in Planning Applications
summary: The need to mitigate and adapt to climate change should also be considered in preparing and assessing planning applications, taking into account the full range of potential climate change impacts.

policy_title: Planning New Development for Climate Change
summary: New development should be planned to avoid increased vulnerability to climate change impacts, ensuring risks in vulnerable areas can be managed through suitable adaptation (e.g., green infrastructure, sustainable drainage), and to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions (through location, orientation, design). Local building sustainability requirements in plans should reflect national technical standards policy.

policy_title: Increasing Use and Supply of Renewable and Low Carbon Energy and Heat in Plans
summary: To increase renewable/low carbon energy and heat use/supply, plans should: provide a positive strategy maximising potential for suitable development (and future re-powering/life extension) while ensuring adverse impacts (including cumulative landscape/visual) are addressed; consider identifying suitable areas and supporting infrastructure; and identify opportunities for development to draw energy from decentralised/renewable/low carbon systems and co-locate heat customers/suppliers.

policy_title: Expectations for New Development Regarding Decentralised Energy and Energy Consumption
summary: In determining planning applications, LPAs should expect new development to: comply with development plan policies on local decentralised energy supply requirements (unless shown unfeasible/unviable by applicant considering development type/design); and take account of landform, layout, building orientation, massing, and landscaping to minimise energy consumption.

policy_title: Supporting Energy Efficiency and Low Carbon Heating in Existing Buildings
summary: LPAs should give significant weight to supporting energy efficiency and low carbon heating improvements to existing buildings (domestic and non-domestic), including heat pumps and solar panels not covered by permitted development. Where proposals affect conservation areas, listed buildings, or other relevant designated heritage assets, policies in Chapter 16 apply.

policy_title: Determining Applications for Renewable and Low Carbon Energy Development
summary: When determining applications for all forms of renewable/low carbon energy development and associated infrastructure, LPAs should: not require applicants to demonstrate overall need, and give significant weight to benefits of generation and contribution to net zero; recognise value of small-scale/community-led projects in cutting emissions; and for repowering/life-extension of existing sites, give significant weight to benefits of utilising an established site.

policy_title: Commercial Scale Renewable Energy Projects Outside Identified Areas
summary: Once suitable areas for renewable and low carbon energy are identified in plans, LPAs should expect subsequent applications for commercial scale projects outside these areas to demonstrate the proposed location meets the criteria used in identifying suitable areas.

policy_title: Avoiding Inappropriate Development in Flood Risk Areas
summary: Inappropriate development in areas at risk of flooding should be avoided by directing development away from areas at highest risk (existing or future). Where necessary in such areas, development should be safe for its lifetime without increasing flood risk elsewhere.

policy_title: Strategic Policies and Strategic Flood Risk Assessment (SFRA)
summary: Strategic policies should be informed by a strategic flood risk assessment (SFRA) and manage flood risk from all sources. They should consider cumulative impacts in/affecting flood-susceptible local areas and take account of advice from the Environment Agency and other relevant flood risk management authorities (lead local flood authorities, internal drainage boards).

policy_title: Sequential, Risk-Based Approach in Plans for Flood Risk
summary: All plans should apply a sequential, risk-based approach to development location, considering all flood risk sources and current/future climate change impacts, to avoid flood risk to people/property where possible. This involves: applying sequential and then exception tests; safeguarding land for flood management; using new development/green infrastructure opportunities to reduce flood causes/impacts (using natural flood management); and seeking opportunities to relocate existing development from unsustainable locations.

policy_title: Sequential Risk-Based Approach for Individual Applications (Flood Risk)
summary: A sequential risk-based approach should also be taken for individual applications in areas known to be at current or future flood risk from any form, by following the steps set out below (paras 174-175).

policy_title: Aim of the Sequential Test (Flood Risk)
summary: The aim of the sequential test is to steer new development to areas with the lowest flood risk from any source. Development should not be allocated or permitted if reasonably available appropriate sites exist in lower flood risk areas. The SFRA provides the basis for applying this test.

policy_title: Application of the Sequential Test (Flood Risk)
summary: The sequential test should be used in areas known to be at current or future flood risk, unless a site-specific flood risk assessment demonstrates no built development (including access/escape routes, land raising, vulnerable elements) would be in an area at risk from any source, now or in the future (considering potential flood risk changes).

policy_title: Exemptions from Sequential and Exception Tests (Minor Development and Changes of Use)
summary: Some minor development and changes of use are exempt from the sequential test and exception test, but must still meet site-specific flood risk assessment requirements (footnote 63).
cross_references: footnote 62 (This includes householder development, small non-residential extensions (with a footprint of less than 250m²) and changes of use; except for changes of use to a caravan, camping or chalet site, or to a mobile home or park home site, where the sequential and exception tests should be applied as appropriate.)
targets: footprint of less than 250m² (small non-residential extensions)

policy_title: Applying the Exception Test (Flood Risk)
summary: If, after applying the sequential test, development cannot be located in lower flood risk areas (considering wider sustainable development objectives), the exception test may be applied. This depends on potential vulnerability of the site and proposed development, per Flood Risk Vulnerability Classification (Annex 3).

policy_title: Criteria for Passing the Exception Test (Flood Risk)
summary: The exception test application should be informed by a strategic or site-specific flood risk assessment. To pass, it must be demonstrated that: a) the development provides wider sustainability benefits to the community outweighing flood risk; AND b) the development will be safe for its lifetime considering user vulnerability, without increasing flood risk elsewhere, and where possible, will reduce overall flood risk.

policy_title: Satisfying Both Elements of the Exception Test
summary: Both elements of the exception test (wider sustainability benefits and safety/no increased risk) must be satisfied for development to be allocated or permitted.

policy_title: Reapplying Exception Test for Allocated Sites
summary: For applications on sites allocated via the sequential test in the development plan, applicants need not reapply the sequential test. However, the exception test may need reapplying if relevant aspects were not considered at plan-making, or if more recent flood risk information exists.

policy_title: Requirements for Development in Flood Risk Areas (Site-Specific FRA)
summary: When determining any planning applications, LPAs must ensure flood risk is not increased elsewhere. Applications should be supported by a site-specific FRA where appropriate. Development in flood risk areas is only allowed if, in light of this assessment (and sequential/exception tests if applicable), it's demonstrated that: most vulnerable development is in lowest flood risk areas on-site (unless overriding reasons); development is appropriately flood resistant/resilient for quick return to use after a flood; it incorporates SuDS (unless clearly inappropriate).
cross_references: footnote 63 (A site-specific flood risk assessment should be provided for all development in Flood Zones 2 and 3. In Flood Zone 1, an assessment should accompany all proposals involving: sites of 1 hectare or more; land identified by the Environment Agency as having critical drainage problems; land identified in a strategic flood risk assessment as being at increased flood risk in future; or land that may be subject to other sources of flooding, where its development would introduce a more vulnerable use.)

policy_title: Further Requirements for Development in Flood Risk Areas (Residual Risk and Access/Egress)
summary: Continuing from para 181, development in flood risk areas must also demonstrate that: d) any residual risk can be safely managed; and e) safe access and escape routes are included where appropriate, as part of an agreed emergency plan.

policy_title: Sustainable Drainage Systems (SuDS) for Drainage Affecting Applications
summary: Applications potentially affecting drainage on/around site should incorporate SuDS to control flow rates and reduce runoff volumes, proportionate to proposal nature/scale. These should provide multifunctional benefits where possible (water quality, biodiversity, amenity). SuDS for major development should: take Lead Local Flood Authority advice; have appropriate proposed minimum operational standards; and have maintenance arrangements for acceptable lifetime operation.

policy_title: Coastal Change: Considering Marine Policy and Integrated Coastal Zone Management
summary: In coastal areas, planning policies and decisions should consider the UK Marine Policy Statement and marine plans. Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM) should be pursued across local authority and land/sea boundaries for effective alignment of terrestrial and marine planning regimes.

policy_title: Reducing Risk from Coastal Change in Plans
summary: Plans should reduce risk from coastal change by avoiding inappropriate development in vulnerable areas and not exacerbating coastal physical change impacts. They should identify as a Coastal Change Management Area (CCMA) any area likely to be affected by coastal physical changes, and be clear on appropriate development in such areas and make provision for relocating development/infrastructure from CCMAs.

policy_title: Appropriate Development in a Coastal Change Management Area (CCMA)
summary: Development in a CCMA is appropriate only if demonstrated that: it will be safe over its planned lifetime and not unacceptably impact coastal change; coastal character (including designations) is not compromised; it provides wider sustainability benefits; and it doesn't hinder creation/maintenance of a continuous signed/managed coastal route.
cross_references: footnote 64 (As required by the Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009.)

policy_title: Limiting Planned Lifetime of Development in CCMAs
summary: LPAs should limit the planned lifetime of development in a CCMA through temporary permission and restoration conditions, where necessary to reduce potentially unacceptable future risk to people and development.

policy_title: Contributing to and Enhancing the Natural and Local Environment
summary: Planning policies and decisions should contribute to and enhance the natural and local environment by: protecting/enhancing valued landscapes, biodiversity sites, geological value, soils; recognising countryside character/beauty and natural capital/ecosystem service benefits (including best agricultural land, trees, woodland); maintaining undeveloped coast character (improving access); minimising biodiversity impacts and providing net gains (establishing coherent ecological networks, supporting priority/threatened species); preventing unacceptable pollution/land instability risks and improving local environmental conditions (air/water quality); and remediating/mitigating despoiled/degraded/derelict/contaminated/unstable land.

policy_title: Strategic Approach to Natural Environment in Plans
summary: Plans should: distinguish between international, national, and locally designated sites hierarchy; allocate land with least environmental/amenity value (consistent with other NPPF policies); take a strategic approach to maintaining/enhancing habitat networks and green infrastructure; and plan for natural capital enhancement at catchment/landscape scale across LPA boundaries.
cross_references: footnote 65 (Where significant development of agricultural land is demonstrated to be necessary, areas of poorer quality land should be preferred to those of a higher quality.)

policy_title: Conserving and Enhancing Landscape and Scenic Beauty in Protected Landscapes
summary: Great weight should be given to conserving and enhancing landscape and scenic beauty in National Parks, the Broads, and National Landscapes (highest status of protection for these issues). Wildlife and cultural heritage conservation/enhancement are also important considerations in these areas and should be given great weight in National Parks and the Broads. Development scale/extent within these areas should be limited; development within their setting should be sensitively located/designed to avoid/minimise adverse impacts.
cross_references: footnote 66 (English National Parks and the Broads: UK Government Vision and Circular 2010 provides further guidance...)

policy_title: Major Development in Protected Landscapes (National Parks, Broads, National Landscapes)
summary: When considering applications for development within National Parks, the Broads, and National Landscapes, permission for major development should be refused other than in exceptional circumstances and where it can be demonstrated to be in the public interest. Consideration includes assessment of: need for development (including national considerations, impact on local economy); cost/scope for developing outside designated area or meeting need otherwise; and any detrimental effect on environment, landscape, recreational opportunities, and extent of moderation.
cross_references: footnote 67 (For the purposes of paragraphs 190 and 191, whether a proposal is 'major development' is a matter for the decision maker...)

policy_title: Development in Heritage Coasts
summary: Within areas defined as Heritage Coast (not already in para 189 designated areas), planning policies and decisions should be consistent with the area's special character and conservation importance. Major development within a Heritage Coast is unlikely to be appropriate unless compatible with its special character.

policy_title: Protecting and Enhancing Biodiversity and Geodiversity in Plans
summary: To protect and enhance biodiversity and geodiversity, plans should: identify, map and safeguard components of local wildlife-rich habitats and wider ecological networks (including site hierarchy, wildlife corridors, stepping stones, areas for habitat management/enhancement/restoration/creation identified by partnerships); and promote conservation, restoration and enhancement of priority habitats, ecological networks, and protection/recovery of priority species, identifying/pursuing opportunities for measurable net gains for biodiversity.
cross_references: footnote 68 (Circular 06/2005 provides further guidance in respect of statutory obligations for biodiversity and geological conservation...)
footnote 69 (Where areas that are part of the Nature Recovery Network are identified in plans, it may be appropriate to specify the types of development that may be suitable within them.)
targets: measurable net gains for biodiversity

policy_title: Principles for Determining Planning Applications Affecting Biodiversity
summary: When determining planning applications, LPAs should apply principles: refuse if significant biodiversity harm cannot be avoided (by alternative site), adequately mitigated, or (last resort) compensated; normally refuse development on/outside SSSI likely to have adverse effect (unless benefits clearly outweigh SSSI feature impact and broader network impacts); refuse development causing loss/deterioration of irreplaceable habitats (ancient woodland, veteran trees) unless wholly exceptional reasons and suitable compensation exist; and support development primarily conserving/enhancing biodiversity, integrating biodiversity improvement opportunities into design for measurable net gains or enhanced public nature access.
cross_references: footnote 70 (For example, infrastructure projects... where the public benefit would clearly outweigh the loss or deterioration of habitat.)

policy_title: Protection Equivalent to Habitats Sites
summary: The following should be given the same protection as habitats sites: potential Special Protection Areas (pSPAs) and possible Special Areas of Conservation (pSACs); listed or proposed Ramsar sites; and sites identified or required as compensatory measures for adverse effects on habitats sites, pSPAs, pSACs, and listed/proposed Ramsar sites.
cross_references: footnote 71 (Potential Special Protection Areas, possible Special Areas of Conservation and proposed Ramsar sites are sites on which Government has initiated public consultation...)

policy_title: Presumption in Favour and Habitats Sites
summary: The presumption in favour of sustainable development does not apply where a plan or project is likely to have a significant effect on a habitats site (alone or in combination), unless an appropriate assessment has concluded the plan/project will not adversely affect the habitats site's integrity.

policy_title: Ensuring Site Suitability Regarding Ground Conditions and Contamination
summary: Planning policies and decisions should ensure: a site is suitable for its proposed use considering ground conditions and risks from land instability/contamination (including natural hazards, former mining, mitigation impacts); after remediation, land is not determinable as contaminated land under Part IIA of Environmental Protection Act 1990; and adequate site investigation information by a competent person is available for assessments.

policy_title: Responsibility for Securing Safe Development (Contamination/Stability)
summary: Where a site is affected by contamination or land stability issues, responsibility for securing a safe development rests with the developer and/or landowner.

policy_title: Appropriateness of New Development Regarding Pollution
summary: Planning policies/decisions should ensure new development is appropriate for its location considering likely pollution effects (including cumulative) on health, living conditions, and natural environment, and site/wider area sensitivity to development impacts. They should: mitigate/reduce to minimum potential adverse noise impacts (avoiding significant adverse impacts on health/quality of life); identify/protect tranquil areas prized for recreational/amenity value; and limit light pollution impact on local amenity, dark landscapes, nature conservation.
cross_references: footnote 72 (See Explanatory Note to the Noise Policy Statement for England (Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs, 2010).)

policy_title: Air Quality Management
summary: Planning policies/decisions should sustain and contribute towards compliance with relevant limit values or national objectives for pollutants, considering Air Quality Management Areas (AQMAs), Clean Air Zones (CAZs), and cumulative impacts. Opportunities to improve air quality or mitigate impacts (e.g., traffic management, green infrastructure) should be identified, preferably at plan-making stage. Decisions should ensure new development in AQMAs/CAZs is consistent with local air quality action plan.

policy_title: Integrating New Development with Existing Businesses and Community Facilities (Agent of Change)
summary: Planning policies/decisions should ensure new development can integrate effectively with existing businesses/community facilities (places of worship, pubs, music venues, sports clubs). Existing businesses/facilities should not have unreasonable restrictions placed on them due to development permitted after they were established. Where an existing business/facility operation could significantly adversely affect new development (including change of use) nearby, the applicant ('agent of change') should provide suitable mitigation before development completion.

policy_title: Focus of Planning System vs. Pollution Control Regimes
summary: Planning policies/decisions should focus on whether proposed development is an acceptable land use, rather than controlling processes/emissions subject to separate pollution control regimes. Planning decisions should assume these regimes will operate effectively. Where a planning decision is made, planning issues should not be revisited through permitting regimes operated by pollution control authorities.

policy_title: Significance and Conservation of Heritage Assets
summary: Heritage assets range from local historic value sites/buildings to highest significance ones like World Heritage Sites (internationally recognised Outstanding Universal Value). These are irreplaceable resources and should be conserved appropriately to their significance for enjoyment by existing/future generations' quality of life.
cross_references: footnote 73 (Some World Heritage Sites are inscribed by UNESCO to be of natural significance rather than cultural significance; and in some cases they are inscribed for both their natural and cultural significance.)

footnote 74 (The policies set out in this chapter relate, as applicable, to the heritage-related consent regimes for which local planning authorities are responsible under the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, as well as to plan-making and decision-making.)
Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990

policy_title: Positive Strategy for Conservation and Enjoyment of the Historic Environment in Plans
summary: Plans should set out a positive strategy for historic environment conservation and enjoyment, including for heritage assets most at risk (neglect, decay, threats). This strategy should consider: desirability of sustaining/enhancing heritage asset significance and viable uses consistent with conservation; wider social, cultural, economic, environmental benefits of historic environment conservation; desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character/distinctiveness; and opportunities to draw on historic environment's contribution to place character.

policy_title: Designation of Conservation Areas
summary: When considering conservation area designation, LPAs should ensure an area justifies such status due to its special architectural or historic interest, and that the concept of conservation is not devalued by designating areas lacking special interest.

policy_title: Historic Environment Record (HER)
summary: LPAs should maintain or have access to a historic environment record (HER). This should contain up-to-date evidence about the area's historic environment and be used to: assess heritage asset significance and their environmental contribution; and predict likelihood of discovering currently unidentified heritage assets (especially archaeological sites).

policy_title: Public Accessibility of Historic Environment Information
summary: LPAs should make information about the historic environment, gathered during policy-making or development management, publicly accessible.

policy_title: Applicant's Description of Significance for Heritage Assets
summary: In determining applications, LPAs should require applicants to describe significance of any affected heritage assets, including setting contribution. Detail level should be proportionate to asset importance and sufficient to understand potential impact. Minimum: relevant HER consulted, assets assessed with appropriate expertise. For sites including/potentially including archaeological assets, LPAs should require desk-based assessment and, where necessary, field evaluation.

policy_title: Assessing Impact of Proposals on Heritage Assets
summary: LPAs should identify and assess particular significance of any heritage asset potentially affected by a proposal (including by development affecting setting), using available evidence and necessary expertise. This assessment should be used when considering proposal impact on asset, to avoid/minimise conflict between asset conservation and proposal aspects.

policy_title: Deliberate Neglect or Damage to Heritage Assets
summary: Where evidence of deliberate neglect or damage to a heritage asset exists, the asset's deteriorated state should not be taken into account in any decision.

policy_title: Considerations in Determining Applications Affecting Heritage Assets
summary: In determining applications, LPAs should consider: desirability of sustaining/enhancing heritage asset significance and putting them to viable uses consistent with conservation; positive contribution heritage asset conservation can make to sustainable communities (including economic vitality); and desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character/distinctiveness.

policy_title: Removal or Alteration of Historic Statues, Plaques, Memorials or Monuments
summary: When considering applications to remove/alter a historic statue, plaque, memorial, or monument (listed or not), LPAs should regard importance of their retention in situ and, where appropriate, explaining their historic/social context rather than removal.

policy_title: Considering Potential Impacts: Weight Given to Conservation of Designated Heritage Assets
summary: When considering impact of proposed development on significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to asset conservation (more important asset = greater weight). This applies irrespective of whether potential harm is substantial, total loss, or less than substantial.

policy_title: Justification for Harm to or Loss of Designated Heritage Assets
summary: Any harm to, or loss of, significance of a designated heritage asset (from alteration, destruction, or development in setting) requires clear and convincing justification. Substantial harm to/loss of: Grade II listed buildings or Grade II registered parks/gardens should be exceptional; assets of highest significance (scheduled monuments, protected wreck sites, registered battlefields, Grade I/II* listed buildings, Grade I/II* registered parks/gardens, World Heritage Sites) should be wholly exceptional.
cross_references: footnote 75 (Non-designated heritage assets of archaeological interest, which are demonstrably of equivalent significance to scheduled monuments, should be considered subject to the policies for designated heritage assets.)

policy_title: Refusal for Substantial Harm or Total Loss of Designated Heritage Asset
summary: Where proposed development leads to substantial harm to (or total loss of significance of) a designated heritage asset, LPAs should refuse consent, unless it's demonstrated the substantial harm/total loss is necessary for substantial public benefits outweighing that harm/loss, OR all of following apply: asset nature prevents all reasonable uses; no viable use found via appropriate marketing for conservation; conservation by grant-funding/not-for-profit/charitable/public ownership demonstrably not possible; AND harm/loss is outweighed by benefit of bringing site back into use.

policy_title: Less than Substantial Harm to Designated Heritage Assets
summary: Where a development proposal leads to less than substantial harm to significance of a designated heritage asset, this harm should be weighed against public benefits of the proposal including, where appropriate, securing its optimum viable use.

policy_title: Effect on Non-Designated Heritage Assets
summary: Effect of an application on significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determination. In weighing applications directly/indirectly affecting non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, regarding scale of any harm/loss and heritage asset significance.

policy_title: Ensuring New Development Proceeds After Heritage Asset Loss
summary: LPAs should not permit loss of whole/part of a heritage asset without taking all reasonable steps to ensure new development will proceed after the loss has occurred.

policy_title: Recording Heritage Assets to be Lost
summary: LPAs should require developers to record and advance understanding of significance of any heritage assets to be lost (wholly/partially) in a manner proportionate to their importance/impact, and make this evidence (and any archive generated) publicly accessible. However, ability to record past evidence should not factor in deciding if such loss is permitted.
cross_references: footnote 76 (Copies of evidence should be deposited with the relevant historic environment record, and any archives with a local museum or other public depository.)

policy_title: Opportunities for Enhancement within Conservation Areas and World Heritage Sites Settings
summary: LPAs should look for opportunities for new development within Conservation Areas and World Heritage Sites, and within setting of heritage assets, to enhance or better reveal their significance. Proposals preserving setting elements that positively contribute to asset (or better reveal significance) should be treated favourably.

policy_title: Assessing Loss of Contributing Elements in Conservation Areas or World Heritage Sites
summary: Not all elements of a Conservation Area or World Heritage Site necessarily contribute to its significance. Loss of a building (or other element) making a positive contribution to significance of the Conservation Area/World Heritage Site should be treated as substantial harm (para 214) or less than substantial harm (para 215), as appropriate, considering relative significance of element affected and its contribution to overall significance of the Conservation Area/World Heritage Site.

policy_title: Enabling Development for Heritage Assets
summary: LPAs should assess whether benefits of a proposal for enabling development, which would otherwise conflict with planning policies but would secure future conservation of a heritage asset, outweigh disbenefits of departing from those policies.

policy_title: Essential Supply and Conservation of Minerals
summary: It is essential to have a sufficient supply of minerals for infrastructure, buildings, energy, and goods. As minerals are finite natural resources workable only where found, best use must be made of them for long-term conservation.

policy_title: Planning Policies for Minerals
summary: Outlines requirements for planning policies regarding minerals, including providing for extraction, considering alternatives, safeguarding resources, encouraging prior extraction, safeguarding related sites, setting environmental criteria, managing noise, and ensuring reclamation.

policy_title: Providing for Mineral Extraction (Excluding Peat)
summary: Planning policies should provide for the extraction of mineral resources of local and national importance, but not identify new sites or extensions to existing sites for peat extraction.

policy_title: Considering Substitute, Secondary, and Recycled Materials for Minerals
summary: Planning policies should, as far as practicable, account for the contribution of substitute or secondary/recycled materials and minerals waste to material supply before considering primary material extraction, while aiming to source minerals indigenously.

policy_title: Safeguarding Mineral Resources
summary: Planning policies should safeguard mineral resources by defining Mineral Safeguarding Areas (MSAs) and Mineral Consultation Areas (MCAs), and adopting policies so known locations of specific local/national importance minerals are not sterilised by non-mineral development (without creating a presumption of working).
cross_references: footnote 77 (Primarily in two tier areas as stated in Annex 2: Glossary)

policy_title: Encouraging Prior Extraction of Minerals
summary: Planning policies should set out policies to encourage prior extraction of minerals, where practical and environmentally feasible, if non-mineral development needs to take place.

policy_title: Safeguarding Mineral-Related Infrastructure and Sites
summary: Planning policies should safeguard existing, planned, and potential sites for: bulk transport, handling, processing of minerals; manufacture of concrete/concrete products; and handling, processing, distribution of substitute, recycled, secondary aggregate material.

policy_title: Criteria for Permitted and Proposed Mineral Operations (Environmental Impacts)
summary: Planning policies should set out criteria or requirements to ensure permitted and proposed mineral operations do not have unacceptable adverse impacts on the natural/historic environment or human health, considering cumulative effects from multiple impacts from individual sites and/or multiple sites in a locality.

policy_title: Noise Limits for Mineral Extraction
summary: When developing noise limits for mineral extraction, planning policies should recognise that some noisy short-term activities, otherwise potentially unacceptable, are unavoidable to facilitate minerals extraction.

policy_title: Reclamation and Aftercare of Mineral Sites
summary: Planning policies should ensure worked land is reclaimed at the earliest opportunity, considering aviation safety, and that high-quality restoration and aftercare of mineral sites occurs.

policy_title: Determining Mineral Extraction Applications: Weight to Benefits
summary: When determining planning applications, great weight should be given to benefits of mineral extraction, including to the economy (except for coal extraction, where para 230 applies). Minerals planning authorities should consider specific criteria when considering proposals.
cross_references: footnote 78 (Except in relation to the extraction of coal, where the policy at paragraph 230 of this Framework applies.)

policy_title: Maintenance of Non-Energy Mineral Landbanks (Location)
summary: Minerals planning authorities should, as far as practical, provide for maintenance of landbanks of non-energy minerals from outside National Parks, the Broads, National Landscapes, World Heritage Sites, scheduled monuments, and conservation areas.

policy_title: Ensuring No Unacceptable Adverse Impacts from Mineral Extraction
summary: Minerals planning authorities should ensure there are no unacceptable adverse impacts from mineral extraction on the natural/historic environment, human health, or aviation safety, and consider cumulative effects from multiple impacts/sites.

policy_title: Controlling Noise, Dust, Particle Emissions, and Blasting Vibrations from Mineral Extraction
summary: Minerals planning authorities should ensure any unavoidable noise, dust, particle emissions, and blasting vibrations from mineral extraction are controlled, mitigated, or removed at source, and establish appropriate noise limits for extraction near noise-sensitive properties.
cross_references: footnote 79 (National planning practice guidance on minerals sets out how these policies should be implemented.)
national planning practice guidance on minerals

policy_title: Prohibiting Peat Extraction from New or Extended Sites
summary: Minerals planning authorities should not grant planning permission for peat extraction from new or extended sites.

policy_title: Restoration and Aftercare of Mineral Sites (Application Stage)
summary: Minerals planning authorities should provide for restoration and aftercare of mineral sites at the earliest opportunity, to high environmental standards, through appropriate conditions. Bonds or financial guarantees for planning conditions should only be sought in exceptional circumstances.

policy_title: Meeting Demand for Building Stone for Heritage Asset Repair
summary: Minerals planning authorities should consider how to meet demand for building stone needed for heritage asset repair, considering the need to protect designated sites.

policy_title: Recognising Small-Scale Nature of Building and Roofing Stone Quarries
summary: Minerals planning authorities should recognise the small-scale nature and impact of building and roofing stone quarries, and the need for a flexible approach to planning permission duration reflecting intermittent or low rate of working at many sites.

policy_title: Development Proposals in Mineral Safeguarding Areas (MSAs)
summary: Local planning authorities should not normally permit other development proposals in Mineral Safeguarding Areas if it might constrain potential future use for mineral working.

policy_title: Planning for a Steady and Adequate Supply of Aggregates
summary: Minerals planning authorities should plan for a steady and adequate supply of aggregates by: preparing an annual Local Aggregate Assessment (LAA); participating in an Aggregate Working Party (AWP); and making provision for land-won/other LAA elements in mineral plans.

policy_title: Form of Aggregate Provision
summary: Provision for aggregates should take the form of specific sites, preferred areas, and/or areas of search and locational criteria as appropriate.

policy_title: Using National and Sub-National Aggregate Guidelines
summary: Minerals planning authorities should take account of any published National and Sub-National Guidelines on future aggregate provision as a guideline when planning for future demand and supply.

policy_title: Using Aggregate Minerals Landbanks as Indicators
summary: Minerals planning authorities should use landbanks of aggregate minerals reserves principally as an indicator of aggregate supply security, and to indicate additional provision needed for new extraction/alternative supplies in mineral plans.

policy_title: Maintaining Aggregate Landbanks (Sand/Gravel and Crushed Rock)
summary: Minerals planning authorities should maintain landbanks of at least 7 years for sand and gravel and at least 10 years for crushed rock, while ensuring operational capacity to supply a wide range of materials is not compromised.
cross_references: footnote 80 (Longer periods may be appropriate to take account of the need to supply a range of types of aggregates, locations of permitted reserves relative to markets, and productive capacity of permitted sites.)
targets: at least 7 years for sand and gravel
at least 10 years for crushed rock

policy_title: Ensuring Competition with Large Landbanks
summary: Minerals planning authorities should ensure that large landbanks bound up in very few sites do not stifle competition.

policy_title: Separate Landbanks for Specific Aggregate Materials
summary: Minerals planning authorities should calculate and maintain separate landbanks for any aggregate materials of a specific type or quality which have a distinct and separate market.

policy_title: Planning for a Steady and Adequate Supply of Industrial Minerals
summary: Minerals planning authorities should plan for a steady and adequate supply of industrial minerals by: cooperating with neighbouring/distant authorities; encouraging safeguarding/stockpiling; maintaining permitted reserves stock for plant investment/maintenance; and considering need for brick clay from multiple sources for blends.
cross_references: footnote 81 (These reserves should be at least 10 years for individual silica sand sites; at least 15 years for cement primary (chalk and limestone) and secondary (clay and shale) materials to maintain an existing plant, and for silica sand sites where significant new capital is required; and at least 25 years for brick clay, and for cement primary and secondary materials to support a new kiln.)
targets: at least 10 years reserves for individual silica sand sites
at least 15 years reserves for cement primary/secondary materials (existing plant)
at least 25 years reserves for brick clay
at least 25 years reserves for cement primary/secondary materials (new kiln)

policy_title: Planning for On-Shore Oil and Gas Development
summary: Minerals planning authorities should, when planning for on-shore oil and gas development, clearly distinguish between, and plan positively for, the three phases (exploration, appraisal, production), ensuring appropriate monitoring and site restoration. They should also encourage underground gas/carbon storage and associated infrastructure if feasible; indicate acceptable areas for coal extraction/colliery spoil disposal; encourage methane capture from coal mines; and provide for separate extraction/stockpiling of fireclay.

policy_title: Integrity and Safety of Underground Storage Facilities
summary: When determining planning applications, minerals planning authorities should ensure integrity and safety of underground storage facilities are appropriate, considering gas pressure maintenance, gas leakage prevention, and pollution avoidance.

policy_title: Planning Permission for Coal Extraction
summary: Planning permission should not be granted for coal extraction unless: the proposal is environmentally acceptable, or can be made so by conditions/obligations; OR if not environmentally acceptable, it provides national, local, or community benefits clearly outweighing likely impacts (considering all relevant matters, including residual environmental impacts).

policy_title: Material Consideration of Framework Policies from Publication Date
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: The policies in this Framework are material considerations to be taken into account in dealing with applications from the day of its publication. Plans may also need revision to reflect policy changes made by this Framework.

policy_title: Status of Existing Policies in Decision-Making and Out-of-Date Criteria for Housing Policies
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: Existing policies should not be considered out-of-date simply due to this Framework's publication; weight depends on consistency. However, where an LPA can demonstrate a five-year housing land supply (with buffer per para 78) AND the Housing Delivery Test shows delivery >75% of requirement over previous three years, policies should NOT be regarded as out-of-date based on the latest local housing need figure being greater than the adopted requirement, for five years from plan adoption.
targets: five year supply of deliverable housing sites
Housing Delivery Test more than 75% over previous three years
five years from the date of the plan's adoption

policy_title: Status of Examined Annual Position Statements
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: Where a local planning authority has a confirmed housing land supply position for a year through a published Annual Position Statement examined by the Planning Inspectorate against a previous Framework version, this position will stand until the Annual Position Statement expires.

policy_title: Application of This Framework Version for Local Plan Preparation
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: For preparing local plans, policies in this Framework version apply from 12 March 2025, unless specific transitional arrangements (plan reached Regulation 19 with >=80% LHN, plan submitted for examination by that date, plan implements preceding local plan adopted since March 2020, plan in SDS area at Reg 19, or minerals/waste only plan at Reg 19/submitted) apply.
cross_references: Regulation 19 of the Town and Country Planning (Local Planning) (England) Regulations 2012
Regulation 22 of the Town and Country Planning (Local Planning) (England) Regulations 2012
targets: 12 March 2025 (effective date)
at least 80% of local housing need (for 234a)

policy_title: Examination of Plans Under Previous Framework Versions (Transitional)
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: Where paragraph 234a, b, c, d, or e applies (transitional arrangements for local plans), the plan will be examined under the relevant previous version of the Framework.

policy_title: Consequence for Submitted Plans with Low Housing Requirement (Transitional)
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: Where paragraph 234b applies (plan submitted by 12 March 2025) and the adopted plan's housing requirement is less than 80% of local housing need, the LPA will be expected to begin work on a new plan under the Levelling Up and Regeneration Act 2023 system (once provisions are in force in 2025) to address the housing shortfall.
targets: less than 80% of local housing need
2025 (LURA plan-making system)

policy_title: Examination Timescales for Plans at Regulation 19 with Low Housing Requirement (Transitional)
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: Local plans reaching Regulation 19 by 12 March 2025 with a draft housing requirement less than 80% of local housing need should proceed to examination within 18 months from 12 December 2024 (or 24 months if plan returns to Regulation 18 stage). This does not apply to plans in areas with an operative SDS providing the housing requirement.
targets: 12 March 2025 (Regulation 19 deadline)
less than 80% of local housing need
18 months from 12 December 2024 (examination deadline)
24 months from 12 December 2024 (examination deadline if returned to Reg 18)

policy_title: Application of This Framework Version to Spatial Development Strategies (SDS)
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: For Spatial Development Strategies, policies in this Framework version will apply to strategies reaching consultation under section 335(2) of the Greater London Authority Act 1999 after 12 March 2025. Strategies reaching this stage on or before this date will be examined under the relevant previous Framework version.
cross_references: section 335(2) of the Greater London Authority Act 1999
targets: 12 March 2025 (consultation deadline for previous NPPF application)

policy_title: Application of This Framework Version to Neighbourhood Plans
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: For neighbourhood plans, policies in this Framework version will apply for preparing plans from 12 March 2025, unless a neighbourhood plan proposal has been submitted to the LPA under Regulation 15 of the Neighbourhood Planning (General) Regulations 2012 on or before 12 March 2025.
cross_references: Regulation 15 of the Neighbourhood Planning (General) Regulations 2012 (as amended)
targets: 12 March 2025 (effective date/submission deadline for previous NPPF application)

policy_title: Application of Policy on Larger-Scale Development (Paragraph 22)
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: The policy on larger-scale development in paragraph 22 (requiring a vision of at least 30 years) applies only to plans that had not reached Regulation 19 stage when the Framework version of 20 July 2021 was published.
targets: 20 July 2021 (NPPF publication date determining applicability of para 22)

policy_title: Application of March 2012 NPPF for Certain Plan Examinations
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: Policies in the original National Planning Policy Framework (March 2012) will continue to apply for examining plans submitted on or before 24 January 2019.
targets: 24 January 2019 (submission deadline for March 2012 NPPF examination)

policy_title: Application of This Framework to Withdrawn or Subsequent Plans/Strategies
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: Where plans or strategies are withdrawn or otherwise do not become part of the development plan, policies in this Framework will apply to any subsequent plan or strategy produced for the area concerned.

policy_title: Exploring Planning Freedoms and Flexibilities
policy_type: National Planning Policy Framework - Annex 1: Implementation
summary: The Government will continue to explore with individual areas the potential for planning freedoms and flexibilities, for example, where this would facilitate an increase in the amount of housing that can be delivered.
